{{Use British English|date=August 2016}} {{BLP sources|date=April 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2014}} {{Infobox economist | name = Richard Blundell | native_name = | native_name_lang = | school_tradition = | image = Richard Blundell Photo.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Sir Richard Blundell CBE | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1952|05|01}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | institution = [[University College London]] | field = | alma_mater = [[London School of Economics]] | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors= | doctoral_students= [[Costas Meghir]]
[[John Van Reenen (economist)|John Van Reenen]]
[[Nicholas Bloom]][https://stanford.app.box.com/s/psf5loukdknxdcr9gds8krevme3xgazd Bloom's CV] Retrieved 2016-10-02. | notable_students = | influences = | influenced = | contributions = | awards =[[Knight Bachelor|Knighthood]] [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]], [[Erwin Plein Nemmers Prize in Economics|Nemmers Prize]] | memorials = | spouse = | signature = | module = | repec_prefix = e | repec_id = pbl81 }} '''Sir Richard William Blundell''' [[Order of the British Empire|CBE]] [[British Academy|FBA]] (born 1 May 1952, [[Shoreham-by-Sea]]) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[economist]] and [[econometrician]]. Blundell is the [[David Ricardo]] Professor of [[Political Economy]] at [[University College London]] and the Director of the [[ESRC]] Centre for the Microeconomic Analysis of Public Policy at the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]].http://www.ifs.org.uk/about/blog/322 He was the Research Director at the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies]] between 1986-2016. He is a Fellow of the [[Econometric Society]] (1991), Fellow of the [[British Academy]] (1996), Honorary Member of the [[American Economic Association]] (2001), Honorary Member [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (2002) and Honorary Fellow of the [[Institute of Actuaries]] (2003). Blundell has received honorary doctorates from the [[University of St. Gallen]], Switzerland in 2003; the [[University of Mannheim]] in 2011; the Norwegian School of Economics [[NHH]], Bergen in 2011; the [[Università della Svizzera Italiana|Università della Svizzera italiana]], Switzerland in 2016; the University of Bristol in 2017 and the University of Venice Ca Foscari in 2018. He was [[Knight Bachelor|knighted]] in the 2014 New Year Honours for services to economics and social science.{{London Gazette|issue=60728 |supp=y|page=1|date=31 December 2013}} ==Career== Blundell received his [[B.Sc.]] in economics and statistics from [[University of Bristol]] in 1973 before he graduated with a master's degree in econometrics and mathematical economics from the [[London School of Economics]] in 1975. He held a position as [[Lecturer]] in Econometrics at the [[University of Manchester]] from 1975 to 1984. He was appointed Professor of Economics at [[University College London]] in 1984 and Research Director of the [[Institute for Fiscal Studies|IFS]] in 1986, before establishing the ESRC Centre for the Microeconomic Analysis of Fiscal Policy at [[Institute for Fiscal Studies|IFS]] in 1991. He was [[Visiting Professor]] of Economics at [[UBC]] in 1980, at [[MIT]] in 1993 and at [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]] in 2000. He was co-editor of ''[[Econometrica]]'' from 1997 to 2001 and co-editor of the ''[[Journal of Econometrics]]'' from 1992 to 1997. He currently edits [http://microeconomicinsights.org/ Microeconomic Insights]. In 2004 Blundell became President of the [[European Economic Association]], in 2006, President of the [[Econometric Society]] in 2010, President of The Society of Labor Economics and served as President of the [[Royal Economic Society]] (2010-2012). ==Awards== In 1995, Blundell received the [[Yrjö Jahnsson Award]], given by the [[European Economic Association]] every two years to the best young economist in Europe, for his work in microeconometrics and the analysis of labour supply, welfare reform and consumer behaviour. In 2000 he was awarded the [[Econometric Society]]'s [[Frisch Medal]], awarded every two years for empirical or theoretical applied research published in ''[[Econometrica]]'' during the previous five years. In 2008 he was recipient of the Jean-Jacques Laffont Prize 2008 given by the [[Toulouse School of Economics]] to an international high level economist whose research combines both the theoretical and applied aspects of economics. He was the 2010 Distinguished [[Center for Economic Studies]] Fellow, an annual prize given by the CES of the [[Ludwig Maximilian University]] of Munich to an outstanding economist who has greatly contributed to the understanding of economic policy problems. In 2012 he was recipient of the [[IZA Prize in Labor Economics]] awarded by [[Institute for the Study of Labor|IZA]] for outstanding academic achievements in the field of labor economics. In 2014, Blundell received, with [[David Card]], the [[BBVA Foundation Frontiers of Knowledge Award]] in Economics, Finance and Management for "their contributions to empirical microeconomics," in the words of the jury’s citation. "Motivated by important empirical questions, they developed and estimated appropriate econometric models, making significant methodological contributions in the process. Both are known for their attention to institutional detail, careful and innovative research design, rigorous application of econometric tools, and dispassionate reporting of results." In 2016 Blundell received the [[Erwin Plein Nemmers Prize in Economics|Nemmers Prize in Economics]] for "his important contributions to labor economics, public finance and applied econometrics". ==Publications== He has published six books and many articles on [[econometrics]], [[microeconomics]], [[consumer behaviour]], [[public economics]] and [[labour economics]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.debretts.com/people/biographies/browse/b/18257/Richard%20William+BLUNDELL.aspx Debrett's People of Today] *[http://www.ucl.ac.uk/~uctp39a UCL webpage] *[http://www.ifs.org.uk/ IFS website] *[https://ideas.repec.org/e/pbl81.html RePEc website (list of papers)] *{{worldcat id|lccn-n85-33527}} {{Yrjö Jahnsson Award recipients}} {{Frisch Medal recipients}} {{Presidents of the European Economic Association}} {{Presidents of the Econometric Society}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Blundell, Richard}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Academics of University College London]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of Bristol]] [[Category:20th-century economists]] [[Category:21st-century economists]] [[Category:English economists]] [[Category:Labor economists]] [[Category:Commanders of the Order of the British Empire]] [[Category:Econometricians]] [[Category:Presidents of the Econometric Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the British Academy]] [[Category:Knights Bachelor]] [[Category:People from Shoreham-by-Sea]] [[Category:Fellows of the Econometric Society]] [[Category:Fellows of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] [[Category:Alumni of the London School of Economics]] [[Category:Education economists]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Sanjaya Malakar | image = Sanjaya_at_Seattle_Center.JPG | caption = Sanjaya Malakar at the Mural Amphitheater, Seattle Center, Seattle, WA on May 12, 2007. | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Sanjaya Joseph Malakar | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1989|9|10|mf=yes}} | origin = [[Federal Way, Washington]], United States | occupation = Singer, reality [[celebrity|television personality]], writer | instrument = Vocals, guitar, [[Electronic keyboard|keyboard]] | genre = Pop | years_active = 2006–present | website = }}'''Sanjaya Joseph Malakar''' (born September 10, 1989) is an American singer, who was a finalist on the [[American Idol (season 6)|sixth season]] of ''[[American Idol]]''. He gained national attention on the series, controversially advancing to 7th place with public votes, despite being poorly received by the show's judges, particularly [[Simon Cowell]].<ref>[http://www.zeenews.com/Entertainment/Movies-Theatre/2007-04-16/366008news.html Sanjaya became one of the biggest obsession of Americans.]{{dead link|date=December 2011}}</ref>
After ''Idol'', Malakar made many television guest appearances and has been commonly parodied in popular culture. He placed 5th in [[I'm a Celebrity... Get Me out of Here! (US season 2)|season two]] of the reality television show ''[[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (U.S. TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]''. He recently won the Remington's Got Talent in Whitefish, MT.
== Early life == Malakar was born in [[Capitol Hill (Seattle)|Capitol Hill]], in downtown [[Seattle]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Dancing to the Music in My Head: Memoirs of the People's Idol |author1=Sanjaya Malakar |author2=Alan Goldsher |publisher=Simon and Schuster |date=2009 |page=25}}</ref> the son of Jillian (Recchi) Blyth and Vasudeva Malakar. He later lived in the nearby suburb of [[Federal Way]].<ref name="aboutcom">{{cite web|url=http://seattle.about.com/od/artsentertainment/p/sanjayamalakar.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071127151226/http://seattle.about.com/od/artsentertainment/p/sanjayamalakar.htm|archivedate=2007-11-27|title=Sanjaya Malakar on American Idol|accessdate=2007-04-11}}</ref> His father, a musician, is a [[Bengali people|Bengali]] [[Demographics of India|Indian]] immigrant born in [[Vrindavan]], India.<ref>Mira Kamdar ([[Asia Society]]). [https://web.archive.org/web/20070926225316/http://www.asiasociety.org/pressroom/oped_idol.html Sanjaya: Giving Them Something to Talk About], ''[[ABC News]]'', April 19, 2007.</ref> His mother is American-born, of Italian descent on one side and Dutch, English, and Irish ancestry on the other.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=fCwFX2MYaqcC&pg=PT55&dq=%22And+to+make+the+color+issue+even+more+confusing,+I'm+also+English,+Irish,+Dutch,+and+Italian.+I'm+a+Eurasian+mutt.%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=7RFyVdyuL8SGyATWwICIBA&ved=0CBwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22And+to+make+the+color+issue+even+more+confusing,+I'm+also+English,+Irish,+Dutch,+and+Italian.+I'm+a+Eurasian+mutt.%22&f=false|title=Dancing to the Music in My Head: Memoirs of the People's Idol|first1=Sanjaya|last1=Malakar|first2=Alan|last2=Goldsher|date=January 20, 2009|publisher=Simon and Schuster|accessdate=May 31, 2017|via=Google Books}}</ref> His parents filed for divorce when he was three years old and had been separated for a year prior to doing so. When the divorce was filed, the family had almost no money coming in. His mother and the children were living in a Seattle apartment, and her only income was from welfare{{Citation needed|date=April 2011}}. His mother remarried, but his stepfather died soon afterwards.<ref name="star">{{cite web|url=http://www.starmagazine.com/news/11746|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070502112120/http://www.starmagazine.com/celebrity_news_gossip/entertainment/11746|archivedate=2007-05-02|title=Sanjaya's Secret Heartache|accessdate=2007-04-12}}</ref> Although Malakar spent the majority of his formative years in the Seattle area, he has also lived in both California<ref name="aboutcom" /> and [[Kauai, Hawaii|Kauai]], Hawaii,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/Mar/15/br/br2941085376.html |title=Sanjaya surprises some after surviving 'Idol' cut |accessdate=2007-03-22}}</ref> where he performed with the Hawaii Children's Theater group. While in Seattle, he spent three years with the [[Total Experience Gospel Choir]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Edwards |first=Haley |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2003645910_sanjaya01.html |title="Idol" contestant Sanjaya once distracted teachers; now it's a nation |publisher=Seattletimes.nwsource.com |date=April 1, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref>
Malakar attended Martha Lake Elementary School in [[Lynnwood, Washington]] for elementary school, and the [[Seattle Waldorf School]] and Northshore Junior High School for middle school in [[Bothell, Washington]]. He attended [[Shorecrest High School]] in [[Shoreline, Washington]] during freshman year, and [[Todd Beamer High School]] in [[Federal Way, Washington]] during sophomore year. After his sophomore year, Malakar passed the [[General Educational Development]] test, in order to leave high school early and focus on a music career and on his participation in ''American Idol''.<ref name="aboutcom"/>
== ''American Idol'' == [[File:Malakar, Sanjaya (2007).jpg|right|thumb|After making the top 10, Malakar performed on the [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2007|American Idol Tour]] with fellow ''Idol'' alums, including [[Melinda Doolittle]].]] On September 19, 2006, Malakar, a shy teen,<ref>[http://www.americanidol.com/archive/contestants/season6/sanjaya_malakar/ Sanjaya Malakar], ''[[American Idol]]''.</ref> entered the open audition for ''[[American Idol]]'' at the Seattle Center in [[Seattle]], with his sister Shyamali. Simon Cowell commented that Sanjaya had a better voice than his sister. Both were advanced to the Hollywood round by the judges. Malakar cited [[Stevie Wonder]] as his idol, and sang one of Wonder's signature songs, "[[Signed, Sealed, Delivered I'm Yours]]" at his Seattle audition.<ref name="aboutcom"/>
For his next performance, in Hollywood, Malakar sang "[[Some Kind of Wonderful (Soul Brothers Six song)|Some Kind of Wonderful]]". He was shown tearfully embracing his sister when she was cut, though he progressed to the Top 40. Next, Malakar sang "[[Ain't No Mountain High Enough]]". The judges were largely critical of his performance, though [[Simon Cowell]] admitted that Malakar is popular with the voters while [[Randy Jackson]] and [[Paula Abdul]] gave a more positive appraisal of his "[[You Really Got Me]]" performance in the Top 11.{{Citation needed|date=April 2007}} A 13-year-old girl named [[Ashley Ferl]] was highlighted repeatedly during Malakar's performance in the Top 11 episode, crying tears of joy, although Ferl also cried for [[Melinda Doolittle]], [[Jordin Sparks]], and many other contestants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/17736726/ |title=Dreams do come true for 'Idol' fan |accessdate=2007-03-22}}</ref>
On March 27, 2007, Malakar sang [[No Doubt]]'s "[[Bathwater (song)|Bathwater]]" wearing a [[fauxhawk]] made from multiple ponytails. The style was called the "ponyhawk" by host [[Ryan Seacrest]].<ref name="ryansea">{{cite web|url=http://www.hollyscoop.com/american-idol/ryan-seacrest-gets-everyone-laughing.html |title=Ryan Seacrest Gets Everyone Laughing |publisher=Hollyscoop.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> While singing, Malakar hesitated with some of the words to the song.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bodognation.com/celebrity-gossip/reality-tv-check-po-hawk-nation-and-found-idols.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070701024753/http://www.bodognation.com/celebrity-gossip/reality-tv-check-po-hawk-nation-and-found-idols.html |archivedate=2007-07-01 |title=REALITY TV CHECK: Po-Hawk Nation and Found Idols |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=July 1, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> Simon Cowell remarked, "Sanjaya, I don't think it matters anymore what we say ... I think you are in your own universe and if people like you, good luck." The following night, host Seacrest walked out on stage wearing a wig with the same hairstyle, parodying Malakar.<ref name="ryansea"/>
On April 3, Malakar sang "[[Cheek to Cheek]]", wearing a white suit, donning a slick hairstyle (with a recent cut), and dancing with judge Paula Abdul. Abdul commented, "I get it. I get why people love you. You are charming."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20180728221526/http://news.aol.com/newsbloggers/2007/04/04/sanjaya-dare-to-be-different-and-blake-lewis-mimbo Sanjaya: Dare to be Different]</ref> On the following April 4 results show, it was revealed that Malakar had finished in the "middle three," among nine contestants.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.themoneytimes.com/articles/20070330/american_idol_brings_out_a_string_of_surprises_sligh_exits_malakar_safe-id-103214.html |title='American Idol' brings out a string of surprises |publisher=Themoneytimes.com |date=March 30, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930014502/http://www.themoneytimes.com/articles/20070330/american_idol_brings_out_a_string_of_surprises_sligh_exits_malakar_safe-id-103214.html |archivedate=September 30, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Malakar's performance of "[[Bésame Mucho]]" in the Top 8 on April 10 was his first unanimously well-received performance by the judges in the finals of the competition. During rehearsals [[Jennifer Lopez]] remarked, "I like this kid. I love Sanjaya!" after hearing him sing in Spanish, the only one of the remaining eight contestants to do so on the Latin-theme night.<ref>{{cite web|last=Archives |first=Actress |url=http://www.actressarchives.com/news/sanjaya-malakar-voted-off-of-american-idol |title=Sanjaya Malakar voted off of American Idol |publisher=Actressarchives.com |date=April 19, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110807084557/http://www.actressarchives.com/news/sanjaya-malakar-voted-off-of-american-idol |archivedate=August 7, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref> Randy Jackson commented, "You're one of the smartest contestants I've ever met. That was actually really good. It was," while Simon Cowell offered the halting, "I'm going to hate myself for this. It wasn't horrible."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://realitytvmagazine.sheknows.com/2007/04/10/american-idol-top-eight-%e2%80%93-sanjaya-one-of-the-smartest-contestants-ever/ |title=American Idol Top Eight – Sanjaya One Of The Smartest Contestants Ever |publisher=Realitytvmagazine.sheknows.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> Malakar continued on, entering the Top 7, following that performance on the April 11 results show.
After performing "[[Something to Talk About (Bonnie Raitt song)|Something to Talk About]]" on the previous night, Malakar was placed in the bottom three and was subsequently eliminated in 7th place on April 18, 2007.<ref>[http://www.cnn.com/2007/SHOWBIZ/TV/04/19/american.idol.ap/ CNN.com]{{dead link|date=April 2009}}</ref><ref>[https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20070419/us_nm/americanidol_dc_2 Yahoo! News]{{dead link|date=April 2009}}</ref> Singing his farewell performance, after the line "let's give them something to talk about", he [[ad lib]]bed "other than hair" in place of "how about love".<ref name="sanjigone">{{cite web |url=http://niralimagazine.com/2007/04/he-may-be-gone-but-sanjaya-is-still-our-papaya/ |title=He May Be Gone, But Sanjaya Is Still Our Papaya |publisher=Niralimagazine.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110930013820/http://niralimagazine.com/2007/04/he-may-be-gone-but-sanjaya-is-still-our-papaya/ |archive-date=September 30, 2011 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
''[[American Idol]]'''s ratings dropped 9% in the episode following Malakar's elimination, which was ''[[Idol Gives Back]]'', a charity episode featuring many celebrity guests. The music news website Moldolva.org reported that this was due to Malakar's departure.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://music.moldova.org/news/american-idol-highest-ratings-due-to-sanjaya-44947-eng.html |title="American Idol" highest ratings due to Sanjaya |publisher=Music.moldova.org |date=April 30, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117101509/http://music.moldova.org/news/american-idol-highest-ratings-due-to-sanjaya-44947-eng.html |archivedate=January 17, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
On the May 23 ''American Idol'' finale, he performed with the top six males, introduced [[Smokey Robinson]] in the medley. Malakar performed "You Really Got Me" with [[Aerosmith]] guitarist [[Joe Perry (musician)|Joe Perry]] on guitar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ca.entertainment.yahoo.com/s/12032007/6/entertainment-aerosmith-rock-india-first-time.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070315073046/http://ca.entertainment.yahoo.com/s/12032007/6/entertainment-aerosmith-rock-india-first-time.html |archivedate=2007-03-15 |title=Aerosmith to rock India for the first time |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=March 15, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref>

=== Public reaction ===
Malakar was the season's most talked about ''American Idol'' contestant, based on articles and searches conducted on the Internet.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/sanjaya_out |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080619043420/http://www.usmagazine.com/sanjaya_out |archivedate=2008-06-19 |title=Buh-Bye-Ya, Sanjaya! |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=June 19, 2008 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://buzzlog.yahoo.com/buzzlog/67409/sanjayas-hair-raising-searches |title=Sanjaya's Hair Raising Searches |publisher=Buzzlog.yahoo.com |date=March 27, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120129142234/http://buzzlog.yahoo.com/buzzlog/67409/sanjayas-hair-raising-searches |archivedate=January 29, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> One ''American Idol'' fan on MySpace claimed to be on a [[hunger strike]] until Malakar was voted off; she later admitted that she was canceling her strike, after his stay was longer than expected. In her YouTube video, an advertisement for a dating site was prominently displayed, causing speculation her hunger strike was really for profit.<ref>{{cite web |date = 2007-03-21 |url=http://entertainment.bodogbeat.com/sanjaya-malakar-inspires-a-hunger-strike-68543.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070328210301/http://entertainment.bodogbeat.com/sanjaya-malakar-inspires-a-hunger-strike-68543.html |archivedate=2007-03-28 |title=Sanjaya Malakar Inspires a Hunger Strike |accessdate=2007-03-22}}</ref> Other members of the MySpace online community created a page entitled Team Sanjaya in support for him. However, members of the online community have contributed semi-fictional web sites, appearing to portray Malakar in a more satirical but supportive way. Websites parodying Malakar's success had also appeared.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070406172327/http://ifsanjayawins.com/ ifsanjayawins.com]. Retrieved June 22, 2007.</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070624040522/http://www.sanjayatheapocalypse.com/ sanjayatheapocalypse.com]. Retrieved June 22, 2007.</ref>
An official fansite for Malakar was created with approval of and contributions by the entertainer and his mother Jillian Blyth,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/sanjaya-malakar/bio/286854 |title=TVGuide |publisher=TVGuide |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> and archives include in-person reports for each [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2007|2007 American Idol Concert Tour]] event.
[[Simon Cowell]] told ''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]'' that had Malakar won, he would not have returned as a judge to the show,<ref name="NYTIMES">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/31/arts/television/31idol.html?ex=1332993600&en=f3eeecfc91e562ea&ei=5088&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss|title=NY Times|accessdate=2007-04-11 | work=The New York Times | first=Edward | last=Wyatt | date=March 31, 2007}}</ref> even though he was contractually obligated to return.<ref name="azcentral">{{cite web|url=http://www.azcentral.com/ent/tv/articles/0404idol0404producer.html|title=AZ Central – Idol Producer|accessdate=2007-04-11}}</ref> The show's executive producer predicted that Malakar would not win.<ref name="azcentral"/> Some commentators have remarked that the judges seemed to have stopped giving thoughtful critiques of Malakar's performances.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://testpattern.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2007/04/03/110885.aspx |title=Simon has no words for Sanjaya |accessdate=2007-04-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070406180041/http://testpattern.msnbc.msn.com/archive/2007/04/03/110885.aspx |archivedate=April 6, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2007/04/has_sanjaya_mal.html|title=Has Sanjaya Malakar ruined the "American Idol" judges?|accessdate=2007-04-11 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070408074603/http://blogs.orlandosentinel.com/entertainment_tv_tvblog/2007/04/has_sanjaya_mal.html |archivedate = 2007-04-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2007/04/03/AR2007040301696.html?hpid=topnews|title=Send In the Clowns. Don't Bother, Sanjaya's Here|accessdate=2007-04-11 | work=The Washington Post | date=April 4, 2007 | first=Lisa | last=de Moraes}}</ref> The judges seemed stunned by his large following of voters.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://blog.gettyimages.com/tag/sanjaya-malakar/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110711091008/http://blog.gettyimages.com/tag/sanjaya-malakar/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 11, 2011 |title=Getty Images – Entertainment Blog » Sanjaya Malakar |publisher=Blog.gettyimages.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011 }}</ref> Randy Jackson went as far to remark that "I cannot even say anything on the vocals anymore", in his critique of Malakar after his performance during the top nine. Chris Ayres of ''[[The Times]]'' speculated that it would have been a turning point leading toward decline and eventual cancellation for ''American Idol'' if Malakar had won.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/us_and_americas/article1582430.ece|title=Why worst crooner's voice may topple American Idol|accessdate=2007-04-15 |work=The Times |location=London | first=Chris | last=Ayres | date=March 29, 2007}}</ref> Others, however, believe that the franchise benefited from the publicity, which was more popular than previous seasons of ''Idol''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/04/04/arts/television/04watc.html|title=Voting Rights Drive 'Idol,' Not the Abuse or the Hair|work=The New York Times|authorlink=Alessandra Stanley|first=Alessandra|last=Stanley|date=2007-04-04|accessdate=2008-03-27}}</ref> On the April 17 broadcast of ''American Idol'', Cowell further said of the controversy, "I know this has been funny for a while, but based on the fact that we are supposed to be finding the next American Idol [Malakar's performance] was hideous."
The weblog [[Vote for the Worst]] had Malakar as its current "pick" for the sixth season top 12 until he was eliminated. On March 19, 2007, [[Howard Stern]] campaigned for his radio show listeners to join the weblog in voting for Malakar "to corrupt the No.1 show on television".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/howard_stern_corrupts_i_idol_i |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731093921/http://www.usmagazine.com/howard_stern_corrupts_i_idol_i |archivedate=2008-07-31 |title=Howard Stern Corrupts Idol! |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=July 31, 2008 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1555113/20070320/id_0.jhtml |title= Is Howard Stern Behind Sanjaya Malakar's Staying Power On 'Idol'? |accessdate=2007-03-22 |date=2007-03-20 |last=Harris |first = Chris | publisher = MTV News}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | first=Edward | last=Wyatt | title=Howard Stern Tries to Kill 'American Idol' With Kindness for a Weak Link | date=2007-03-31 | publisher=[[The New York Times Company]] | url =https://www.nytimes.com/2007/03/31/arts/television/31idol.html?ex=1332993600&en=ecc4f2e2914562da&ei=5124&partner=permalink&exprod=permalink | work =The New York Times | accessdate = 2007-04-03 }}</ref> Some Stern regulars claimed to have voted for Malakar over 300 times—largely in hopes of tormenting ''[[American Idol]]'' traditionalists on the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quchronicle.com/2007/04/vote-for-the-worst-american-idol/ |title=Vote for the Worst American Idol |publisher=Quchronicle.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref><ref name="jkim">{{cite web|author=TstarV |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8xTRD1UKyTc |title=Sanjaya On Jimmy Kimmel Live! 04/26/07 |work=Youtube |date=August 5, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> Later, when asked for a reaction, Malakar told [[Jimmy Kimmel]] that his aunt had voted 1100 times.<ref name="jkim"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://ultrabrown.com/ |title=Ultrabrown |publisher=Ultrabrown |date=June 23, 1985 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111201031537/http://ultrabrown.com/ |archivedate=December 1, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
The fan reaction of [[Ashley Ferl]] was satirized on the March 24, 2007 broadcast of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', during the ''[[Weekend Update]]'' segment. Malakar was portrayed by [[Andy Samberg]], and the crying girl was portrayed by [[Kristen Wiig]]. Also feigning tears in the audience were [[Fred Armisen]] and [[Dan Aykroyd]]. Samberg portrayed Malakar again during the monologue of the April 21, 2007 episode, singing the song "Something To Talk About" as a duet with host [[Scarlett Johansson]].<ref>''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', March 24, 2007</ref> The controversy spawned colloquialisms associated with Malakar's name, such as "Sanjayamania"<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/07/15/PKGRMQTFQV1.DTL | work=The San Francisco Chronicle | title=IDOL WATCH / Sanjayamania | first=Aidin | last=Vaziri | date=July 15, 2007}}</ref> and "Fanjaya" to denote a Sanjaya fan.
=== Homecoming === The [[Federal Way, Washington|Federal Way]] City Council, initially unable to find his address or whereabouts,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/331/story/50083.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070430182911/http://www.thenewstribune.com/331/story/50083.html |archivedate=2007-04-30 |title=Star search: Where's Sanjaya? |accessdate=2007-04-28| author=Maynard, Steve }}</ref> announced plans to honor Malakar. Sanjaya Malakar was greeted by screaming fans at The Commons at Federal Way,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/331/story/58807.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070512193604/http://www.thenewstribune.com/331/story/58807.html |archivedate=2007-05-12 |title=Crowd goes gaga over Sanjaya |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 12, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> and was praised by the city's Mayor Michael Park and King County Council member Peter von Reichbauer for serving as a great role model,<ref>[http://www.seattlepi.com/lifestyle/315019_sanjaya10.html Seattle Pi]{{dead link|date=April 2009}}</ref> with Park stating "Sanjaya's charismatic personality, contagious smile, positive attitude and enthusiastic pursuit of his dreams are qualities to be admired."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/sanjaya-malakar-honored-for-his-unlikely-american-idol-6-journey-5158.php |title=Sanjaya Malakar honored for his unlikely 'American Idol 6' journey |publisher=Realitytvworld.com |accessdate=December 6, 2011}}</ref> Malakar was presented a Certificate of Appreciation from the city<ref>{{cite web |url=http://media.thenewstribune.com/smedia/2007/05/10/06/sanjaya.source.prod_affiliate.5.pdf |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20080308174608/http://media.thenewstribune.com/smedia/2007/05/10/06/sanjaya.source.prod_affiliate.5.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=March 8, 2008 |title=Sanjaya Source Affiliate |date=July 4, 2007 |accessdate=December 6, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref> and declaration of "South King County Sanjaya Malakar Day". In May 2007, he was also honored at [[Seattle Center]] in [[Seattle|Seattle, Washington]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.prlog.org/10016153-seattle-own-sanjaya-returns-home-for-very-special-appearance-at-the-seattle-center.html |title=Seattle's Own Sanjaya Returns Home For A Very Special Appearance At The Seattle Center |publisher=Prlog.org |date=May 7, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> where he was greeted by fans, signed autographs and answered questions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.rickey.org/american-idol/sanjaya-malakar/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120909130042/http://www.rickey.org/american-idol/sanjaya-malakar/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=September 9, 2012 |title=Sanjaya Malakar : rickey.org – American Idol 24/7 |publisher=Rickey.org |date=August 4, 2011 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 }}</ref> The council had received 200 e-mails from around the country asking the city to honor Malakar.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/441/story/54190.html |title=Watch out mall walkers, here comes Sanjaya! |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 13, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070513055257/http://www.thenewstribune.com/441/story/54190.html |archivedate=May 13, 2007 }}</ref>
=== Tour === Since Malakar placed in the top 10, he qualified to perform as part of the [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2007|2007 American Idol Concert Tour]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/?pid=793 |title=American Idols Live Tour '07 Info Here |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=March 29, 2008 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080329174301/http://www.americanidol.com/news/view/?pid=793 |archivedate=March 29, 2008 }}</ref> which, over three months, visited over 50 cities in Canada and U.S.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=77059 |title=Sanjaya is doing great |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 16, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070516073551/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/storypage.aspx?StoryId=77059 |archivedate=May 16, 2007 }}</ref> He performed [[Michael Jackson]]'s "[[The Way You Make Me Feel]]" during the tour.
== Career ==
=== After ''Idol'' ===
Shortly after his run on ''American Idol'' ended, Malakar attended the [[White House Correspondents' Association Dinner]] as a ''[[People Magazine|People]]'' magazine guest, where he saw then-President [[George W Bush]]. Malakar was popular among the press and fans at the dinner, and was even prompted for an autograph by then-New York Governor [[Eliot Spitzer]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Howell |first=Arnesa |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20036187,00.html |title=Sanjaya's a Hit at White House Correspondents' Dinner |work=People |date=April 22, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref>
Several magazines honored the singer, including ''[[Us Weekly]]'', ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'', ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'', and ''[[Teen (magazine)|Teen]]''. He was featured in ''[[Us Magazine]]'''s April 20, 2007, issue in an article entitled "Sanjaya Speaks",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usmagazine.com/sanjaya_speaks |title=Usmagazine.com | Sanjaya Speaks! |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=April 17, 2008 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080417080832/http://www.usmagazine.com/sanjaya_speaks |archivedate=April 17, 2008 }}</ref> where he was asked about his reactions to the parodies, Simon Cowell, Howard Stern and to his new celebrity status. He was featured in the May 7, 2007, issue of ''People'', where he talked about his ''American Idol'' run, his younger years, and future aspirations. The article mentions that he was raised vegetarian, a diet he no longer follows.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20036901,00.html |title=May 7, 2007 – People Magazine |work=People |date=April 26, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> In ''TIME'''s 2007 "TIME 100 POLL for The Most Influential People of the Year", based on online public votes, he ranked third.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/2007/time100walkup/article/0,28804,1611030_1610841_1614001,00.html |title=The TIME 100 – Sanjaya Malakar |work=Time |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |date=April 20, 2007}}</ref> He was nominated for ''Teen'''s 2007 "Top Ten Most Cutest".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.seventeen.com/entertainment/interviews/ |title=Whos Cuter? |publisher=Seventeen.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref>
Award shows acknowledged Malakar, as well. He won two of [[TV.com]]'s Fashion Awards, in the categories of "ON AIR: Best Hair – Male",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/special_feature/fashion/index.html?page=2 |title=ON AIR: Best Hair – Male |publisher=Tv.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070930015320/http://www.tv.com/special_feature/fashion/index.html?page=2 |archivedate=September 30, 2007 |df=mdy }}</ref> and "OFF AIR: Best Trendsetter – Male", by public votes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/special_feature/fashion/index.html?page=23 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130412012138/http://www.tv.com/special_feature/fashion/index.html?page=23 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=April 12, 2013 |title=Best Trendsetter |publisher=Tv.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011 }}</ref> He was nominated for "Best Reality Show Star" in [[AZN Television]]'s annual Asian Excellence Awards<ref>{{cite web|url=http://azntv.com/axawards/ |title=AXA Awards |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=July 18, 2008 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080718052920/http://azntv.com/axawards/ |archivedate=July 18, 2008 }}</ref> and was a presenter at the awards ceremony<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/gallery/0,,20039309_12,00.html |title=Star Tracks |work=People |date=May 18, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> aired May 24, 2007 on [[E!]] and May 28, 2007 on AZN-TV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2007/May/11/br/br8497061532.html |title=Island stars part of Asian TV awards in Los Angeles |publisher=The.honoluluadvertiser.com |date=May 11, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> At the 2007 [[Teen Choice Awards]] on August 26, he was named "Best TV Reality Star".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fox.com/teenchoice/winners/ |title=FOX Broadcasting Company: TEEN CHOICE 2007 |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=August 30, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070830111612/http://www.fox.com/teenchoice/winners/ |archivedate=August 30, 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.waleg.com/celebrities/archives/008838.html |title=Teen Choice Award Nominees Announced August 3, 2007 |publisher=Waleg.com |date=August 2, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> He grabbed a nomination and a win for Fox's 2007 Golden Realitini Awards. At the October 13, 2007 show, he was nominated for "Most Memorable Reality Personality of the Year", and he won the "Favorite Reality Game Loser" award at the awards ceremony, where he was a presenter. Malakar won Fox's 2007 Golden Realitini Award for Favorite Reality Game Loser aired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://really.foxreality.com/2007/ |title=Really Awards 2007 |publisher=Really.foxreality.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> "Sanjaya's Ponyhawk" was ranked as No. 3 in the 2007 "Top TV Moment" video searches by [[AOL]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about-search.aol.com/hotsearches2007/view_all_searches.html |title=AOL 2007 Year End Hot Searches |publisher=About-search.aol.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111203201841/http://about-search.aol.com/hotsearches2007/view_all_searches.html |archivedate=December 3, 2011 |df=mdy }}</ref>
In 2017, he won the Remington's Got Talent, a local show in Whitefish, MT.
=== TV appearances ===
In the months following ''Idol'', Malakar appeared as a guest on multiple television shows, including ''[[The Tonight Show with Jay Leno]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://uberdesi.com/blog/2007/04/20/sanjaya-on-jay-leno/ |title=Sanjaya on Jay Leno |publisher=Uberdesi.com |date=April 20, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Access Hollywood]]'', ''[[Today (NBC program)|The Today Show]]'', ''[[Good Morning America]]'', ''[[Are You Smarter than a 5th Grader]]'', ''[[Live with Regis and Kelly]]'', ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]'', the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', ''[[The Morning Show With Mike and Juliet|The Morning Show]]'', ''[[Extra (U.S. TV program)|Extra]]'', ''[[The Early Show]]'', ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/sanjaya-malakar/credits/286854 |title=Credits – Sanjaya Malakar |publisher=Tvguide.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> and ''[[Rachael Ray (TV series)|The Rachel Ray Show]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rachaelrayshow.com/?q=videos/2007-biggest-month-ever |title=2007 – Biggest Month Ever |publisher=Rachaelrayshow.com |date=November 14, 2011 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> Additionally, he got "slimed" on [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/04/24/entertainment/main2722990.shtml |title=Sanjaya Gets Slimed! |publisher=Cbsnews.com |date=February 11, 2009 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> He also appeared with the rest of the top 10 on ''[[Larry King Live]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tvguide.com/celebrities/sanjaya-malakar/tv-listings/286854 |title=Show Airings |publisher=Tvguide.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Access Hollywood]]'', and ''[[Good Day L.A.]]''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah5535.shtml |title=Life After 'Idol:' Finalists Visit Access Hollywood |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=June 1, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070601202247/http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah5535.shtml |archivedate=June 1, 2007 }}</ref>
Upon meeting [[Billy Ray Cyrus]], Malakar reported discussing a guest spot on Disney Channel's ''[[Hannah Montana (TV series)|Hannah Montana]]'' in an April 20, 2007 interview with Access Hollywood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah4977.shtml |title=What's Next For Sanjaya? |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 9, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070509143729/http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah4977.shtml |archivedate=May 9, 2007 }}</ref>
=== Projects === On May 22, 2007, a one-minute short ''I Am Art'', co-produced with [[Will Ferrell]], was released online with Malakar playing Bill Vendall, a 25-year-old graduate student of the arts, who created the character "Sanjaya Malakar" to appear on ''American Idol'', as an installment of his [[thesis]].<ref>{{cite web|last=O'Donnell |first=Jane |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1560264/20070523/green_day.jhtml |title=A.M. Surf Report: Green Day Rumored For 'American Idol' Finale; Sanjaya Claims He's An Art Project; Benzino Has Plans For Eminem |work=Mtv |date=May 23, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> Malakar released a follow-up video explaining it was a joke, since some believed Bill Vendall was real.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah5501.shtml |title=ROLL CALL: Sanjaya Gets Surreal & Rosie Responds To Fans |publisher=Web.archive.org |date=May 27, 2007 |accessdate=December 12, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070527074227/http://www.accesshollywood.com/news/ah5501.shtml |archivedate=May 27, 2007 }}</ref>
Malakar also hosted an ''American Idol'' show on the ''[[TV Guide]]'' channel called ''Idol Stars: Where Are They Now?'', talking about what past ''Idol'' stars are currently doing. Malakar also mentioned that he was continuing music and he helped write the book, ''[[Chicken Soup for the Soul|Chicken Soup for the American Idol Soul]]''. Malakar also wrote an autobiography entitled ''Dancing to the Music in My Head: Memoirs of the People's Idol'' in 2009. He reported that he received a $100,000 advance for the book.<ref>[http://www.realityblurred.com/realitytv/archives/american_idol_6/2009_Jan_23_sanjaya_book_sex Sanjaya Received a $100,000 Advance for his book] Reality Blurred, January 23, 2009</ref> In India, Malakar received his first acting role, where he starred in a [[Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company]] commercial, where he seeks help from a [[guru]].
In May–June 2009, he starred in the reality show [[I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here! (U.S. season 2)|second season]] of the reality television show ''[[I'm a Celebrity…Get Me out of Here! (U.S. TV series)|I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!]]'' along with [[Torrie Wilson]], [[Holly Montag]], [[Heidi Montag]], [[Spencer Pratt]], [[Stephen Baldwin]], [[Daniel Baldwin]], [[Janice Dickinson]], [[Lou Diamond Phillips]], [[John Salley]], [[Frangela]], and [[Patti Blagojevich]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.votefortheworst.com/20090417/sanjaya_joins_already_vftw_filled_cast_im_celebrity_get_me_out_here |title=Sanjaya Joins An Already VFTW Filled Cast on "I'm a Celebrity, Get Me Out Of Here" |publisher=Votefortheworst.com |date=April 17, 2009 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref><ref name=ct>{{cite news|title=Former Gov. Rod Blagojevich hoping to appear on reality show |first=Stacey |last=St. Clair |work=Chicago Tribune |date=April 15, 2009 |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/politics/chi-talk-blago-realityapr15,0,5649181.story |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5gLseXdwp?url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/politics/chi-talk-blago-realityapr15,0,5649181.story |archivedate=April 27, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }}</ref> On the show he earned the nickname "Jungle Boy" in recognition of how comfortable he appeared in the jungle.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsroom.mtv.com/2009/06/09/sanjaya-has-finally-found-his-lane-on-celebrity/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120711235115/http://newsroom.mtv.com/2009/06/09/sanjaya-has-finally-found-his-lane-on-celebrity/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=July 11, 2012 |title=Sanjaya Has Finally Found His Lane on Celebrity |publisher=Newsroom.mtv.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011 }}</ref> He developed a close friendship with the older Holly Montag, as such, her sister Heidi had dubbed them "SanJolly". They have stated that they are not in a relationship, but do spend considerable time together.
In May 2010, ''[[Seattle Weekly]]'' reported that Malakar was working as a singer for [[Pagliacci Pizza]], a Seattle-based pizzeria chain.<ref>{{cite web|last=Seely|first=Mike|title=American Idol Sanjaya Malakar Now Working, Singing at Pagliacci Pizza|url=http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/voracious/2010/05/american_idol_sanjaya_malakar.php|work=[[Seattle Weekly]]|date=2010-05-04|accessdate=2011-01-09|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100508233132/http://blogs.seattleweekly.com/voracious/2010/05/american_idol_sanjaya_malakar.php|archivedate=May 8, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On February 23, 2011, Malakar joined the off-Broadway musical ''Freckleface Strawberry'' at New World Stages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Freckleface Strawberry – Off-Broadway |url=http://www.broadway.com/shows/freckleface-strawberry/buzz/155193/american-idol-vet-sanjaya-malakar-to-join-freckleface-strawberry |title=American Idol Vet Sanjaya Malakar to Join Freckleface Strawberry |publisher=Broadway.com |date=February 8, 2011 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref>
On February 26, 2011, Malakar was a guest judge for the finals of local Seattle talent competition, "Seattle Superstar Search."<ref>{{cite web|last=Dykstra|first=Eric|title=American Idol Sanjaya Malakar as Guest Judge on Seattle Talent Competition|url=http://seattlesuperstar.tv|work=[[Seattle Superstar Search]]|date=2011-02-09|accessdate=2011-02-09}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
In July 2011 Malakar toured the United States with the band, The Brave Chandeliers.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}}
As of May 2012, Malakar is now a bartender living in [[Queens, New York]]. Of the money he made, Malakar admits most has been lost: "I was young. I didn't know anything. Some people took advantage. Some skimmed a little off the top, financially."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://blog.seattlepi.com/thebigblog/2012/05/21/hey-whatever-happened-to-sanjaya-malakar/ | work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer | title=Hey, whatever happened to Sanjaya Malakar?}}</ref>
As of April 2014, Malakar quit working at an East Village bar to have more time and energy to focus on his music, including his work-in-progress, ''Life ~ Love ~ Music'', and his focus on studio covers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://voices.yahoo.com/the-real-truth-american-idols-sanjaya-malakar-12604926.html?cat=33|title=Yahoo|website=Yahoo|accessdate=May 31, 2017|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140417034838/http://voices.yahoo.com/the-real-truth-american-idols-sanjaya-malakar-12604926.html?cat=33|archivedate=April 17, 2014|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
On July 14, 2016 he performed at the [[Suquamish Clearwater Casino Resort]] in [[Suquamish, Washington]] as part of their Free Summer Lawn Concert series.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clearwatercasino.com/event/sanjaya-malakar-free-concert/|title=Sanjaya Malakar – Free Concert|website=www.clearwatercasino.com|accessdate=May 31, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170824083157/http://www.clearwatercasino.com/event/sanjaya-malakar-free-concert/#|archive-date=August 24, 2017|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
Malakar sings seven jazz standards on the album ''Good Merlin'' by The Chaz Lipp Groove Tripp. The album releases June 23, 2017<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B06XW1JN27|title=Good Merlin|publisher=|accessdate=May 31, 2017|via=Amazon}}</ref> and Malakar has received positive reviews for his performance. Writing for The Morton Report, [[Bill Bentley (record producer)]] says Malakar's voice "goes directly for the core of these American songbook standards."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.themortonreport.com/features/bentleys-bandstand/bentleys-bandstand-may-2017/|title=Bentley's Bandstand: May 2017|first=Bill|last=Bentley|date=May 5, 2017|publisher=|accessdate=May 31, 2017}}</ref> Bill Buckley of the U.K.-based SoulandFunkandJazz describes Malakar's "remarkable voice" as "different, unusual, unexpected."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soulandjazzandfunk.com/news/4775-groove-trippin.html|title=GROOVE TRIPPIN'|first=Bill|last=Buckley|website=www.soulandjazzandfunk.com|accessdate=May 31, 2017}}</ref> [[Blogcritics]] writer Rhetta Akamatsu rated the album 96/100 largely due to Malakar's "incredible, flexible voice."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogcritics.org/music-review-the-chaz-lipp-groove-tripp-good-merlin/|title=Music Review: The Chaz Lipp Groove Tripp – 'Good Merlin'|publisher=|accessdate=May 31, 2017}}</ref> Ronald Jackson of The Smooth Jazz Ride website says "Sanjaya Malakar is truly a singer with brilliant pipes... His passion is clear and bold on each track he engages. Great range and control."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesmoothjazzride.com/the-blues-bus/|title=The Blues Bus|first=Ronald|last=Jackson|website=www.thesmoothjazzride.com|accessdate=June 16, 2017}}</ref>
== Discography == Malakar's American Idol CD album ''Sanjaya Malakar'', and some singles were offered on iTunes starting June 10, 2007. The Sanjaya Malakar album has reached Top 100 Pop Albums in sales.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popvortex.com/music/charts/top-pop-albums.php |title=retrieved June 12, 2007 |publisher=Popvortex.com |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> Malakar's EP ''Dancing to the Music in my Head'' was released on January 20, 2009. Songs from the EP include the singles "A Guy Like Me" and "A Quintessential Lullaby". The EP was released the same day as Malakar's book, titled the same as the EP.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.popeater.com/2009/01/06/idol-sanjaya-set-to-release-5-song-set/ |title='Idol' Sanjaya Set to Release 5 Song Set |publisher=Popeater.com |date=January 6, 2009 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> In 2011, he is also releasing his album ''Life ~ Love ~ Music'' with the pre-release debut single from the album being a cover of "[[Tempted (Squeeze song)|Tempted]]",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://tunes.broadwayworld.com/article/Sanjaya-Malakar-Releases-Tempted-20110523 |title=BroadwayWorld: Sanjaya Malakar Releases Tempted |publisher=Tunes.broadwayworld.com |date=May 23, 2011 |accessdate=December 12, 2011}}</ref> a 1981 hit from [[Squeeze (band)|Squeeze]].
=== Albums === {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Type |- |rowspan="3"|2007 | ''Sanjaya Malakar'' |rowspan="5"|EP |- | ''[[American Idol Season 6: Greatest Hits#The Collector's Edition|American Idol Season 6: The Collector's Edition]]'' |- |''[[American Idol Season 6: Greatest Hits]]'' |- | 2009 | ''[[Dancing to the Music in my Head]]'' |- ||2011 | ''Life ~ Love ~ Music'' |}

Type |- |rowspan="6"|2007 | "[[Ain't No Mountain High Enough]]" |rowspan="6"|EP |- | "[[You Really Got Me]]" |- | "[[Bathwater (song)|Bathwater]]" |- | "[[Cheek to Cheek]]" |- | "[[Bésame Mucho]]" |- | "[[Something to Talk About (Bonnie Raitt song)|Something to Talk About]]" |- ||2011 | "[[Tempted (Squeeze song)|Tempted]]" ||Life ~ Love ~ Music |}

{{Infobox journal | title = Teaching Sociology | cover = Teaching Sociology journals cover.gif | editor = [[Kathleen S. Lowney]] | discipline = [[Sociology]], [[Education]] | abbreviation = Teach. Sociol. | publisher = [[Sage Publications]] for the [[American Sociological Association]] | country = United States | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1973-present | openaccess = | license = | impact = 1.302 | impact-year = 2017 | website = http://ts.lemoyne.edu/tsmain.html | link1 = http://www.asanet.org/page.ww?section=Teaching+Sociology+(Journal)&name=Homepage | link1-name = Journal page at ASA | link2 = http://tso.sagepub.com/ | link2-name = Journal page at Sage | JSTOR = teacsoci | OCLC = 1789172 | LCCN = 73646931 | CODEN = | ISSN = 0092-055X | eISSN = 1939-862X }} '''''Teaching Sociology''''' is a quarterly [[academic journal]] in the field of [[sociology]]. It has been published since 1973 by [[American Sociological Association]]. The journal's goal is to publicize both theoretical and practical information useful for professionals teaching sociology courses.
==History== ''Teaching Sociology'' incorporates ''Teaching Newsletter'' (1979–1985), which was formerly named ''On Teaching Undergraduate Sociology Newsletter'' (197?-1979).
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080221123344/http://www.asanet.org/page.ww?section=Teaching+Sociology+%28Journal%29&name=Homepage Homepage]
