{{Infobox non-profit | name = The Compass Institute Inc. | image = The Compass Institute Inc Logo.jpg | caption =The Compass Institute | founder = [[David Dangerfield]] | purpose = Further education and training for young people with disabilities | founded_date = <!-- {{Start date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location = Sunshine Coast, Queensland, Australia | coordinates = <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LON|display=inline,title}} --> | origins = | key_people = | area_served = Sunshine Coast, Queensland, Australia | products = | services = Disability service | focus = Further education, training and vocational pathways for young people with disabilities | mission = To provide life long learning to young people with disabilities | method = | revenue = | endowment = | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | motto = "Exploring the Art of Life" | former name = The Aikido Institute | homepage = <!-- {{URL|https://www.compassinc.org.au}} --> }}
[[File:The Compass Institute Inc Entrance and Sign.jpg|thumb|right|alt=The entrance to the Dojo and The Compass Institute's Palmwoods centre| The entrance to the Dojo and The Compass Institute's Palmwoods centre]]
'''The Compass Institute Inc.''' is a charity organisation for young Queenslanders with a disability. It is Australia's first accredited Disability Service based on the principles of [[Budō|Japanese Budo]].<ref name=Engel>{{cite news|last=Engel|first=Nicky|title=The Compass Institute- Charting a Course for Change|newspaper=Business Matters Magazine|date=November 2008}}</ref> Compass is a registered member of the National Disability Services, providing post-school services for young people with an intellectual disability.<ref name="nds website">{{cite web|title=National Disability Services|url=https://www.nds.org.au/links/page/3|publisher=NDS website}}</ref>
Compass has been operating as a not for profit organisation since the early 90's.<ref name=Engel/> It began in 1991 as 'The Aikido Institute' providing alternative education and intervention programmes to school-aged children.<ref name=Blitz>{{cite news|title=Aikido School Makes a Difference for Disabled|newspaper=Blitz Australasian Martial Arts Magazine|date=March 2013}}</ref> Between 1992 and 2006 over 7000 children participated in the intervention programmes.<ref name=Engel /><ref name="Win a diamond">{{cite news|title=Support a Local Charity...Win a Diamond!|newspaper=Sunshine Valley Gazette|date=27 March 2013}}</ref><ref name=brian>{{cite news|last=Hall|first=Peter|title=Students Make a Stand for Brian|newspaper=Sunshine Coast Daily|date=21 June 2002|page=10}}</ref> In 2003 The Aikido Institute became The Compass Institute Inc., and began providing post-school education, training and vocational opportunities to young people with intellectual and/or physical disabilities.<ref name=Engel /><ref name=Fudge>{{cite news|last=Fudge|first=Nicole|title=Sporting Chance for Compass to Hit Goals|newspaper=Caloundra Weekly|date=March 23, 2011|page=7}}</ref>
In 2013 Compass is a registered charity employing 30 specialist staff and supporting over 70 young people with intellectual and/or physical disabilities through 6 centres from Gladstone to Gympie.<ref name=Bode>{{cite news|last=Bode|first=Mark|title=Compass on Course|newspaper=Sunshine Coast Daily|date=16 June 2011 |page=8}}</ref> One of these centres is a working farm, which provides opportunities for around 20 young people to gain access to further training in animal husbandry, horticulture, nursery work, and property maintenance.<ref name=Bode />
==Education== The Compass Institute Inc. provides further education in a broad range of subjects. The goal of the Institute is to provide real life skills with a focus on personal development and independent living. This includes literacy, numeracy, communication, fitness, social skills, food preparation, personal grooming, transport and community participation.<ref name="School trans compas web">{{cite web|title=School Transitions|url=https://www.compassinc.org.au/education/school-transitions/|accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref>
Compass employs staff in roles such as teachers, trainers, coaches and mentors, similarly those that attend Compass are students or 'Trainees' and not referred to as 'clients'.
==Training and vocation== The organisation works on making pathways for disabled young people to become increasingly independent.<ref name=Campion>{{cite news|last=Campion|first=Alice|title=Funding a Must for Disabled Teens|url=https://sunshinecoastdaily.com.au/news/funding-must-disabled-teens/7773701|accessdate=4 June 2013|newspaper=Sunshine Coast Daily|date=23 February 2013}}</ref> Central to Compass training and vocation units is the provision of "real further education, skills-based training and vocational opportunities as part of a structured pathway to social and economic participation".<ref name=Campion /> Through the vocational pathways Compass provides, people with a disability have successfully been placed into appropriate and rewarding work.<ref name=Campion /><ref name=Fears>{{cite news|title=Ignoring fears pays off in staff addition|newspaper=Sunshine coast Daily|date=September 23, 2011|page=7}}</ref> The Compass Institute Inc. is involved in setting up [[social enterprise]]s as vocational pathways for its trainees. These are ‘real life’ businesses that are integrated into the local community, including lawn and garden maintenance, Vehicle detailing, business support services, art and craft markets and the Compass Farm.<ref name="community enterprises">{{cite web|title=Community Enterprises|url=https://www.compassinc.org.au/vocations/community-enterprises/|accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref>
The purchase of an 8 hectare property enabled the organisation to set up an innovative educational and vocational setting, known as the Compass Farm.<ref name=Bode /> At this facility trainees can undertake vocational training, work experience and therapy.<ref name=Fencing>{{cite news|title=Fencing for Compass|newspaper=Sunshine Valley News|date=30 September 2011}}</ref> In 2011, 20 people with disabilities, ranging in ages from 20 to 30 undertook training and work programs at the property.<ref name=Bode /> Activities range from animal husbandry, mixed horticulture, nursery work and property maintenance work.<ref name=Bode /><ref name=farm>{{cite web|title=Compass Farm|url=https://www.compassinc.org.au/vocations/compass-farm/|accessdate=28 February 2018}}</ref>
==Martial values== Underpinning the structure and organisation of both the service provision and management of Compass are the philosophies of Japanese Budo.<ref name=Engel /> The early work of the Aikido Institute (now The Compass Institute Inc.) involved running intervention programs and life skills classes that used [[Aikido]] and [[Budō]] to help students with goal setting, anger management, time management, and self-defence.<ref name=High>{{cite news|title=Students Learn to Hold Heads High|newspaper=Sunshine Coast Daily|date=June 21, 2001|page=12}}</ref> These “unique experiential programs” employed the principles of traditional martial arts philosophy and practice to engage students.<ref name="Win a diamond" /> From here Compass branched out into the disability service, but the role of Aikido and budo philosophy has never ceased to have an important role in the running of Compass.
Compass CEO [[David Dangerfield]] has been using martial arts to help build physical skills and self-confidence in people for over 30 years. He saw the potential to do the same with people with both physical or intellectual disabilities.<ref name=Engel /> "These individuals are always reminded of what they can't do, Martial arts is something they can do. It's a great physical outlet..."<ref name=Engel />
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Compass Institute Inc}} [[Category:Special education]] [[Category:Disability organisations based in Australia]] [[Category:Non-profit organisations based in Queensland]] [[Category:1991 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1991]]

{{primary sources|date=August 2015}}
'''Think-pair-share''' is a collaborative teaching strategy first proposed by Frank Lyman of the University of Maryland in 1981. It can be used to help students form individual ideas, discuss and share with the others in-group. It can be used before reading or teaching a concept and works better with smaller groups.<ref name=Ref01>{{cite news|last1=Lyman|first1=Frank|title=Think-pair-share|publisher=MAA-CIE Cooperative News}}</ref>
==Process== In think-pair-share strategy the teacher acts as a facilitator, and poses a question or a problem to the students. The students are given sufficient time to think and gather their thoughts, after which the teacher asks them to pair themselves and share their thoughts with each other.
As the students begin to share their thoughts and views, each learns to see the different perspective of thinking among their peers. By doing so the students learning is enhanced by the formation and articulation of an idea. This also enables the students to have clarity of thought and have the ability to communicate their thoughts and ideas to another student.
If time permits the paired students can share their thought with other paired students, and teachers can ask one or two pairs to share their ideas with the entire class.
Think-pair-share is designed to help the student to understand the concept of the given topic, develop ability to filter the information and formulate an idea or thought, and draw conclusions. The most important aspect of the think-pair-share is that students will develop the ability to consider and appreciate the different viewpoints of their peers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readingrockets.org/strategies/think-pair-share|title=Think-Pair-Share|work=Reading Rockets}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brown.edu/about/administration/sheridan-center/teaching-learning/effective-classroom-practices/think-pair-share|title=Think-Pair-Share|work=Brown University}}</ref>
== Advantages ==
*The process is easy to prepare and takes only a small amount of time to perform in class. *The interaction with students at personal level is intended to motivate those students who may not be generally interested in the topic. *Different kinds and levels of questions can be asked from lower order to higher order thinking questions. *Teacher can understand the different thought processes of the students while listening to the pairs and when the students share their view at the end.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://serc.carleton.edu/introgeo/interactive/tpshare.html|title=Think-Pair-Share|work=Interactive Lectures}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Cooperative learning]] * [[Collaborative learning]]
== References == {{reflist}}
[[Category:Teaching]]

{{about|educational training simulations in business|business video games for entertainment purposes|business simulation game}} In business, '''training simulation''' is a virtual medium through which various types of skills can be acquired.<ref>Gopinath, C. and Sawyer, J. (1999). ''Exploring the Learning from an Enterprise Simulation, Journal of Management Development''</ref> Training simulations can be used in a variety of genres; however they are most commonly<ref>Henfrey, Richard (1989). ''"Executive" simulation'', Executive Development, Vol. 3 Iss: 2</ref> used in corporate situations to improve [[business]] awareness and [[management]] skills. They are also common in academic environments as an integrated part of a business or management course.
The word [[simulation]] implies an imitation of a real-life process, usually via a computer or other technological device, in order to provide a [[lifelike experience]]. This has proven to be a reliable and successful method of training in thousands of industries worldwide.<ref>Ellet, Bill (1997). ''TMR Shortlist of Business Simulations'', Training Media Review Publications</ref> They can be used both to allow specialization in a certain area, and to educate individuals in the workings of the sectors as a whole, making training simulations versatile. Training simulations are not just games;<ref>Klabbers, Jan H. G. (1999). ''Three Easy Pieces: A Taxonomy of Gaming''. In Saunders, Danny and Severn, Jackie (eds.) ''The International Simulation & Gaming Research Yearbook: Simulations and Games for Strategy and Policy Planning''</ref> their aim is to educate and inform in an exciting and memorable way, rather than purely to entertain.
__TOC__
==Purpose==
Companies across the world regularly use simulations as a tool to teach employees.<ref>Shaw, Elizabeth, O’Loughlin, Andrew and McFadzean, Elspeth (2005). ''[http://www.pogc.ir/portals/0/maghalat/890706-2.pdf Corporate Entrepreneurship and Innovation Part 2: A Role- and Process-based Approach]'', European Journal of Innovation Management, Vol. 8 Iss: 4</ref> With the enormous range of simulation-based activities available, it is unsurprising that the specific aims of the sessions vary widely. Some simulations are focused on [[decision making|making decisions]] in a particular area of the business, such as personnel or [[product design]], and these are called ''Functional Simulations''. Others give a general overview of a company and give experience of making executive management decisions, and are called ''Total Enterprise Simulations''.<ref>Biggs, William D. (1990).'' [http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.455.1754&rep=rep1&type=pdf Introduction to Computerized Business Management Simulations].'' In Gentry (ed.) ''Guide to Business Gaming and Experiential Learning''</ref> In recent years, however, this classification has become somewhat impractical, as increasing numbers of training simulations are involving both elements, and combining both an overall view of the industry with some decisions relating to specific sectors.
Training Simulations normally form part of a program designed to educate employees or students about the skills needed to operate a business, as well as persuade them to "[[think outside the box]]" and see the bigger picture.<ref>Duncan, Graham A. ''Home and Away: Application of the Executive Simulation for Education and Training Purposes in Dundee and Malaysia''</ref> This can make for a better organized, more fluid system in which all employees understand their part in making the company successful.
Although the most common use for training simulations is in a [[corporate]] setting,<ref>Declan Doyle, F. William Brown, (2000). ''[https://www.researchgate.net/profile/F_Brown/publication/235314940_Using_a_business_simulation_to_teach_applied_skills_-_The_benefits_and_the_challenges_of_using_student_teams_from_multiple_countries/links/0deec52a5e16008bae000000/Using-a-business-simulation-to-teach-applied-skills-The-benefits-and-the-challenges-of-using-student-teams-from-multiple-countries.pdf Using a business simulation to teach applied skills – the benefits and the challenges of using student teams from multiple countries]'', Journal of European Industrial Training, Vol. 24 Iss: 6</ref> simulation games are increasingly being used to educate young people about the importance of business. From secondary school age all the way up to [[MBA]] students, anyone can benefit from the first-hand experience of running a company and making decisions that directly affect performance.<ref>Prohaska, Charles R. and Frank, Ellen J. (1990). ''[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1046878190211004 Using Simulations to Investigate Management Decision Making]''. Simulation & Gaming, Vol. 21 No. 1</ref> This will allow the participants to gain an overall understanding of the business world, and give some insight into the type of skills that are necessary to succeed.<ref>Elgood, Chris (1996). ''Using Management Games''</ref> It is also important to note that ‘beating the game’ should not be a primary aim for anyone taking part in a simulation; the focus should be directed towards everyone gaining some useful and relevant knowledge that they can take away and use in their daily lives.<ref>Butler, Michael J. R. and Reddy, Peter (2010). ''[http://eprints.aston.ac.uk/20147/1/Butler__Reddy_JEIT_-_Developing_Critical_Understanding_through_EBL_and_Storytelling.pdf Developing Critical Understanding in HRM Students: Using Innovative Teaching Methods to Encourage Deep Approaches to Study]'', Journal of European Industrial Training, Vol. 34 Iss: 8/9</ref> If the simulation does have a competitive element, it is to motivate and inspire, rather than encourage any malpractice.<ref>Hynes, Briga, Costin, Yvonne and Birdthistle, Naomi (2011). ''Practice-based Learning in Entrepreneurship Education: A Means of Connecting Knowledge Producers and Users''. Higher Education, Skills and Work-based Learning, Vol. 1 Iss: 1</ref> Some training activities are non-competitive to avoid this, however many noted experts in the field state that the rivalry between teams or individuals improves the learning experience and adds a sense of fun and drama into the simulation.<ref>Neal, D. J. (1997). ''Group Competitiveness and Cohesion in a Business Simulation''. Simulation & Gaming, Vol. 28 Iss: 4</ref> This is particularly important when working with young people such as students, as they often require an extra boost to keep them entertained, especially when a simulation is run over an extended period.
==Development==
The concept of training employees to have a wider perspective on their position within the workplace has been around for hundreds of years,<ref>Keys, Bernard and Wolfe, Joseph (1990). ''The Role of Management Games and Simulations in Education and Research''. Journal of Management, Vol. 16, No. 2</ref> but it is only relatively recently that the idea of creating a simulated environment for trainees to test their abilities and skills has been developed. The first commercially available training simulation was in 1956, and was called ''The Top Management Decision Game'', and was created by the [[American Management Association]].<ref>Naylor, Thomas H. (1971). ''Computer Simulation Experiments with Models of Economic Systems''.</ref> Since then, the market has expanded hugely, with thousands of simulations available based upon hundreds of different industries. Initially simple with just a few choices to make, some simulations have become extremely complex with many different interlinking decisions. When training simulations were first used, they involved paper forms that were filled in by the participants and then compared by the organizer of the exercise. Nowadays, nearly all simulations are [[computer]] based,<ref>Stuart, John M. (2007). ''Business Simulations - Do They Have a Place in Training?''</ref> and involve multi-stage algorithms that calculate performance based on the decisions entered.<ref>Fripp, John (1997). ''A Future for Business Simulations?'', Journal of European Industrial Training, Vol. 21 Iss: 4</ref> Most simulations are based around a real [[industry]], and hence they use real data to be as accurate as possible and to provide a realistic experience. However, some remain generic and do not model a particular industry, although these tend to be more useful for younger players or those with absolutely no business knowledge.
==Integrated==
Most corporations and academic courses that contain a training simulation integrate it into an existing or completely new training programme.<ref>Faria, A. J. (1987). ''A Survey of the Use of Business Games in Academia and Business''. Simulation & Gaming, Vol. 18 No. 2</ref> This allows the participants to get the maximum value from the experience, as well as review the sessions in order to improve them for future use. The structure of a training session would normally be as follows:
* '''Introduction:''' the organizer of the program (plus sometimes a specialist in the training simulation) will meet the participants and give them a brief explanation of the purposes behind the training and what they should hope to achieve. * '''Lectures:''' sometimes the trainees will also receive one or more lectures around the topics that the simulation will be based on, in order to give them an idea of the type of skills they will need. This is especially important within academia, when the students will often be examined on this section after the event. * '''The simulation:''' the simulation will then be played, allowing newly acquired knowledge to be tested and skills practiced. A positive atmosphere is vital here to maintain enthusiasm. * '''Evaluation:''' once the simulation has been completed, it is important to summarize what has been learnt and the effectiveness of the training. Presenting results to others may provide a means of internal assessment, as well as showcasing the players’ achievements.
This integrated [[training]] will allow everyone taking part in the simulation to get the maximum experience possible, as well as being entertaining, exciting and giving them a new perspective on the business world. Many companies that specialize in training simulations also offer to create a special integrated plan unique to the client,<ref>Wenzler, I (2005). ''[https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/d8bc/e727abf8da27f3dc4497b00499129fd31d78.pdf Development of an asset management strategy for a network utility company: Lessons from a dynamic business simulation approach]''. Simulation & Gaming, Vol. 36 No. 1</ref> to make the process as streamlined and efficient as possible.
==Benefits==
Since training simulations are available based on such a wide range of different industries, and with thousands of different aims and objectives, it is difficult to outline a specific skill-set that will be improved by taking part in a training simulation. However, skills that good training simulations should build on include:
* '''Business awareness''' – before participating in the training programme, many players will have little idea of how to run a business or what it involves. Simulations allow them to temporarily have control over a virtual company, to see whether their decisions lead them to success or failure!<ref>Cruz, Natalia, Escudero, Anna, Barahona, Juan and Leitao, Fernando (2009). ''[http://www.emeraldinsight.com/doi/abs/10.1108/03090590910950578 The Effect of Entrepreneurship Education Programmes on Satisfaction with Innovation, Behaviour and Performance]'', Journal of European Industrial Training, Vol. 33 Iss: 3</ref> * '''Time management and organization''' – most simulations contain timed sessions, which will test the candidates’ skill in submitting decisions within the allotted time slot.<ref>Whicker, Lynn, Marcia and Sigelman, Lee (1991). ''Computer Simulation Applications, An Introduction''</ref> This is an excellent skill for any employee or graduate. * '''Team coordination''' – the majority of training simulations involve working in groups or teams of people;<ref>Wellington, W. J. and Faria, A. J. (1992). ''An Examination on the Effect of Team Cohesion, Player Attitude and Performance Expectations on Simulation Performance Results''</ref> improving the abilities to communicate effectively, delegate tasks and diplomatically resolve any situations. * '''Problem solving''' – simulations will often present tricky circumstances that must be thought through logically to be solved.<ref>Faria, A. J. (2001). ''[http://www.coulthard.com/library/Files/faria_2001_thechangingnatureofbusinesssimulationgamingresearch.pdf The Changing Nature of Business Simulation/Gaming Research: A Brief History]''. Simulation & Gaming, Vol. 32 No. 1</ref> Successful resolution of these shows good management skills.
If every participant improves in these four key skill areas, the training programme will be a success, and any business should notice an improvement in efficiency and motivation, and students will be inspired and animated.<ref>''Business Simulation Means Better Senior Managers at Heinz'', Journal of European Industrial Training, Vol. 23 Iss: 1</ref>
==See also== * [[Business game]] * [[Business simulation]] * [[Business simulation game]] * [[Experiential learning]] * [[Friday Night at the ER]] * [[Microsoft Flight Simulator]] * [[Print simulation]] * [[Project management simulation]] * [[Simulations and games in economics education]] * [[Web-based simulation]]
==References==
{{Reflist}}
[[Category:Business software]] [[Category:Learning methods]] [[Category:Management education]] [[Category:Business education]] [[Category:Simulation software]]

The '''UCLA Language Materials Project''' ('''LMP''') maintains a web resource about teaching materials for some 150 languages that are [[Less Commonly Taught Languages|less commonly taught]] in the [[United States]]. The project, funded by the [[U.S. Department of Education]], was created in 1992. It is part of the [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] Center for World Languages.
== Bibliographic database of teaching materials ==
The website provides full bibliographic information for over 7000 items, including textbooks, readers, phrasebooks, grammars, dictionaries, and supplementary materials that are distributed in print, audio, video, web and computerized instruction formats. It offers detailed descriptions of the content and other features of each material, to help users find the most appropriate tools for their individual teaching and learning needs. Items can be located quickly through menus displayed at the top of each webpage, or through an advanced search. The LMP does not sell the materials listed in the database, but does provide information on retailers and distributors where the materials can be obtained.
== Database and guide to authentic materials ==
The website also provides citations of about 1000 Authentic Materials, language materials originally intended for [[native speaker]]s rather than [[second-language learner]]s. Because such items reflect current culture and actual language usage, they are much valued as teaching tools. The database presents native-language posters, signs, advertisements, product labels, games, maps, schedules, and brochures that can be downloaded for free from the LMP website. There are also links to selected external websites that offer native-language audio, video, and print resources. The Authentic Materials page provides a guide to using those materials in the classroom, including sample lesson plans.
== Language profiles ==
Each LMP language has its own webpage, providing a language profile, a direct link to the LMP citations for that language, and links to relevant external websites for teachers and students of the language. The profile provides a map, a description of key dialects, grammatical features, relationship to other languages, a [[linguistic history]], and sociolinguistic information.
== Materials reports ==
These reports provide a numeric summary of the categories of materials cited for each language in the database. They are used by publishers and policy makers to assess the U.S. availability of teaching materials for a given language.
== CARLA database ==
A direct link to the [[University of Minnesota]]'s database of the courses in less commonly taught languages offered by over 2000 schools, colleges and other programs in the U.S. and Canada. CARLA stands for Center for Advanced Research on Language Acquisition.
== CAL database ==
An additional database of teaching materials for less commonly taught languages, produced by the Center for Applied Linguistics in Washington, DC, and hosted by the LMP. It offers brief summaries of materials for languages beyond the 150 in the LMP database.
== Links for language teachers ==
The LMP website offers selected links to language resource centers, professional language teachers' associations, scholarly publications, and distributors of language-teaching materials.
== K-12 language-teaching resources ==
A separate portal for people teaching less commonly taught languages to students in kindergarten through 12th grade. Offerings include a section on curricular frameworks and standards, links to dozens of outside resources for [[K-12]] language teachers, and a year's worth of free lesson plans for teachers to download and adapt to their own classrooms. The lessons are grouped into thematic units (e.g. 10 lessons on school, 5 lessons on likes and dislikes, 15 on friends and relationships), and offer lively activities for learning to communicate in the target language.
== External links == * {{official website|http://www.lmp.ucla.edu}} {{UCLA}}
[[Category:Linguistics organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 1992]] [[Category:Linguistic maps]] [[Category:Language education materials]]

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Ukrainian Admission Center |nativename = Український Приймальний Центр |nativename_a = УПЦ |logo_width =150px |seal =Ukrainian_Admission_Center_Logo.png |formed = May 14, 2016 |jurisdiction = [[Ukraine]] |headquarters = Nauki Avenue 40, 64, [[Kharkiv]] |employees = 24 |website = [http://ukraine.admission.center/ Official website] |footnotes = }} The '''Ukrainian Admission Center''' ({{lang-uk|Український Приймальний Центр}}) is the official Ukrainian organization founded with support of [[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]]. Meanwhile, '''Ukrainian Admission Center''' is a private company and a part of AbroStudy LLC<ref>[http://abrostudy.com AbroStudy - Education Abroad for International Students]</ref>.
==History== On April 11, 2016, it was decided to create international organization that will helps international students with admission and education abroad. After analyzing the situation, it was revealed that students experience difficulties when entering abroad. This is primarily due to the fake agents. The new organization should resolve this problem. The Ukrainian Admission Center was launched on a test mode. A year later, after the analysis of it work, similar centers will be launched in several other countries: [[Russia]], [[Belarus]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] and [[Poland]], Perhaps in [[Hungary]], [[Cyprus]], [[Kazakhstan]]
'''Ukrainian Admission Center''' was founded on 14 May 2016. In first month of work there was more than 1500 applications from foreign students.<ref>[http://zakon1.rada.gov.ua/laws/show/242-91-%D0%BF Declaration of Cabinet of Ministers]</ref>
Since january 2017 Ukrainian Admission Center works in normal mode.
==Structures== The center consists of the central body with headquarter in [[Kharkiv]] and offices in the largest universities in regional centers: *[[Kiev]] *[[Vinnytsia]] *[[Dnipro]] *[[Zhytomyr]] *[[Zaporizhia]] *[[Ivano-Frankivsk]] *[[Lutsk]] *[[Lviv]] *[[Mykolaiv]] *[[Odessa]] *[[Poltava]] *[[Rivne]] *[[Sumy]] *[[Ternopil]] *[[Kharkiv]] *[[Kherson]]
==See also== *[[Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine]] *[[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine]] *[[Higher education in Ukraine]] *[[List of universities in Ukraine]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130725132533/http://mon.gov.ua/en Official Website of the Ukrainian Ministry of Education] * [http://ukraine.admission.center/ Official Website of the Ukrainian Admission Center] * AbroStudy - Study Abroad for International students * [http://www.ibe.unesco.org/International/ICE47/English/Natreps/reports/ukraine_en_ocr.pdf]

revision.text:
{{Infobox school | name = University of North Texas
College of Music | image = Murchison 1.jpg | imagesize = 340px | caption = Winspear Auditorium, Murchison Performing Arts Center, University of North Texas College of Music (photo by Craig D. Blackmon, FAIA, courtesy of Holzman Moss Architecture) | motto = | established = 1890 | type = Public | dean = John W. Richmond | campus = Suburban | enrollment = 1,510 (2015–16) | homepage = {{url|http://music.unt.edu}} }} The '''University of North Texas College of Music''', based in [[Denton, Texas|Denton]], is a comprehensive music school among the largest enrollment of any music institution accredited by the [[National Association of Schools of Music]]. [http://music.unt.edu/about UNT School of Music - About] It developed the first jazz studies program in the nation, and it remains one of the top schools for [[Jazz]]. As one of thirteen colleges and schools at the [[University of North Texas]], it has been among the largest music institutions of higher learning in North America since the 1940s. North Texas has been a member of the [[National Association of Schools of Music]] for {{age|1939|01|01}} years. Since the 1970s, approximately one-third of all North Texas music students have been enrolled at the graduate level. Music at North Texas dates back to the founding of the university in 1890 when [[Eliza Jane McKissack]], its founding director, structured it as a conservatory. ==Overview== The College of Music is a comprehensive institution of international rank.{{Cite web | title = U.S. News and World Report 2012 Rankings | url = http://colleges.usnews.rankingsandreviews.com/best-colleges/unt-3594| accessdate = September 13, 2011 |work=[[U.S. News & World Report]] |year=2011}} Its heritage dates back {{Cardinal to word|{{age|format=raw|1890|09|01}}}} years, when North Texas was founded. The college has one of the largest enrollment of any music institution accredited by the [[National Association of Schools of Music]],''HEADS Data – Special Report, 2010–11'', [[National Association of Schools of Music]] of which it has been a member for {{age|1939|01|01}} years. It has been among the largest music institutions of higher learning in North America since the 1940s. The college awards [[bachelor of music]], [[master of music]], [[doctor of philosophy]], and [[Doctor of Musical Arts|doctor of musical arts]] degrees and non-degree graduate artist certificates. Concentrations include performance, [[music composition]], [[music education]], [[music history]], [[music theory]], [[ethnomusicology]], and jazz studies. Its size, its array of disciplines organized across eight academic divisions, its six research centers, its six major ensemble areas that produce over 70 ensembles, and the number of degrees offered — from bachelor's degrees to doctorates to artist certificates — allows the college the achieve the type of critical mass to be highly comprehensive (wide and deep) and prolific in academics, research, and performance, from big to small to standard to experimental to esoteric. In performance, the public review of the college's total work is presented through over 1,000 student and faculty concerts, annually, which include fully mounted opera, grand chorus, symphonic orchestra, early music, chamber music, jazz, orchestra, winds, experimental music, intermedia, and ethno music. The [[music library]], founded in 1941, has one of the largest music collections in the United States, with over 300,000 volumes of books, periodicals, scores, and approximately 900,000 sound recordings. Since the 1970s, approximately one-third of all North Texas music students have been enrolled at the graduate level. North Texas was first in the world to offer a degree in jazz studies. [[U.S. News and World Report]], in its annual ''America's Best Graduate Schools'', ranked the jazz studies program as the best in the country every year from 1994, when it began ranking graduate jazz programs, to 1997, when it retired the category.[[US News and World Report]] The [[One O'Clock Lab Band]] has been nominated for 7 [[Grammy Awards]]. == Degrees, divisions, and centers == The College of Music offers 19 programs leading to degrees and 1 leading to an artist certificate:''Higher Education Data Service Data – Special Report, 2010-11'', [[National Association of Schools of Music]] Note: For more than 20 years, North Texas Music enrollment has tracked closely to that of [[Jacobs School of Music|Indiana]]. Institutions that include [[Berklee]], [[Juilliard]], [[Manhattan School of Music]] are not among the 627 NASM members. One non-NASM music school has a student enrollment larger than North Texas – [[Berklee]]. {| border="0" cellpadding="0" style="border:1px solid #A3B1BF; color: black; background-color: white;" |-valign="bottom" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:Beige"| | style="background-color:Beige"|North Texas | style="background-color:Beige"|[[Jacobs School of Music|Indiana]] |-valign="bottom" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2006-07 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,649 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,638 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2007-08 | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|1,659 | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|1,633 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2008-09 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,608 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,554 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|2009-10 | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|1,635 | style="background-color:#FFFFE0"|1,557 |-valign="center" style="text-align:center" | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|2010-11 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,596 | style="background-color:#FFF8DC"|1,578 |} === Divisions === {|width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" style="border:1px solid #A3B1BF; [[University of North Texas College of Music Opera|Workshop]] |width="16.67%"; style="background-color:White"| |width="16.67%"; style="background-color:White"| |width="16.67%"; style="background-color:White"| |width="16.67%"; style="background-color:#FFFFE0"| |} == Former deans & current dean == {| border="0" cellpadding="5" style="color: black; background-color: #FFFFFF;" |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1890–1891''' |width="90%"|'''[[Eliza Jane McKissack]]''' (''{{linktext|née}}'' '''Aykroyd''') (aka '''Mrs. Alexander Cogle McKissack''') (1828–1900) served as Director of what then was called '''Conservatory of Music''', part of what then was the '''Texas Normal College and Teacher Training Institute''', which was established as a private institution in 1890. Classes were first held Tuesday, September 16, 1890. |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1891–1892''' |width="90%"|'''Mary Francis Long''',"Kaleidoscope of Society: Denton," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' Vol. III, No. 224, June 28, 1892, pg. 3, col. 4 from [[Geneva, Illinois]], was an 1891 graduate of [[Chicago Musical College]] where, during her senior year, she won the William M. Hoyt Prize (the Diamond Medal for the best student in harmony in the graduating class)"Musical College Commencement," ''[[Chicago Daily Tribune]]'', June 24, 1891 |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1894–?''' |width="90%"|'''Sarah ("Sallie") Frances Thornley'''[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86071158/1895-04-08/ed-1/seq-8/ "Happy Prosperous Denton: North Texas Normal College,"] ''Fort Worth Gazette,'' April 8, 1895, pg. 8, col. 2 (''{{linktext|née}}'' '''Cummings''') (b. 1854 [[Mason County, Kentucky]]; d. 11 July 1921 [[Dallas, Texas]]; buried at the [[Independent Order of Odd Fellows|I.O.O.F.]] Cemetery, [[Denton, Texas]]) — was originally from [[Maysville, Kentucky]].[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87060190/1894-08-15/ed-1/seq-3/ "Personal,"] ''Evening Bulletin,'' [[Maysville, Kentucky]], August 15, 1894, col. 4Obituary: "Mrs. Sallie Thornley," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' July 13, 1921 Around 1883 (ending January 1884), Thornley had been a music teacher at Georgetown Female Seminary in [[Georgetown, Kentucky]]."Personals," ''Daily Evening Bulletin'' ([[Maysville, Kentucky]]), January 23, 1884, pg. 3, col. 2 In January 1884, Thornley enrolled at the [[University of Cincinnati – College-Conservatory of Music|College of Music of Cincinnati]]. In Maysville, Thornley taught music and was the organist at [[Methodist Episcopal Church, South|M. E. Church, South]]."Brooks-Adamson," ''Daily Evening Bulletin'' ([[Maysville, Kentucky]]), March 26, 1885, pg. 3, col. 2 In the spring of 1885, Thornley had served as head of music at a college in [[Sherman, Texas]]."Personals," ''Daily Evening Bulletin'' ([[Maysville, Kentucky]]), June 25, 1885, pg. 4, col. 3 Around 1887, Thornley had been a music teacher at [[Georgetown College (Kentucky)|Georgetown College]] in [[Georgetown, Kentucky]].[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87060190/1893-05-15/ed-1/seq-2/ "Personal,"] ''Daily Evening Bulletin'', [[Maysville, Kentucky]], May 15, 1893, pg. 2, col. 2 |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1894–?''' |width="90%"|'''Miss Edith Miller''[http://texashistory.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metapth21918/m1/14/?q=music%20%22texas%20normal%22 D. M. Anderson Directory Co.'s Business Directory and Handy Guide of Denton,]'' pg. 14 (1894) |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1896–1897''' ---- |width="90%"|'''Celia Goldsmith''' ---- |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1901–1902''' |width="90%"|'''Mary Stuart Butler''' (23 March 1871 [[Kirkwood, Missouri]] — 29 November 1944 [[San Marcos, Texas]]) was the first music faculty of record after North Texas became a state institution in 1899. She was appointed by the [[Texas Education Agency#State Board of Education|Texas State Board of Education]] on July 6, 1901."Faculty of the North Texas Normal Completed," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' July 7, 1901, pg. 23, col. 4 She was a vocal instructor who led a lifetime advocacy of music in public schools, not just for "intellectual luxury and restful agency," but for cultural and practical uses ranging from [[physiological]] development to self-expression to public speaking (enunciation, tones)."State Schools of Methods," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' June 22, 1897 Prior to North Texas, Butler had overseen music education in the [[Austin Independent School District|Austin Public Schools]]. After North Texas, she held positions at [[Texas State University]] in San Marcos (then a teachers college) and [[Louisiana Tech University]]. |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1902–1912''' |width="90%"|'''Margaret Manora Boylan''' (born 1867, [[Hubbard, Iowa]]; d 1963, [[Carthage, Missouri]]) served as Director of Music and Reading. Before beginning a career of teaching on the faculties of several colleges throughout the country, she had attended summer school at Ginn summer school in Chicago, [[New England Conservatory]] ("NEC"),"Carthage Woman's Song Broadcast on Radio," ''[[The Joplin Globe]],'' February 12, 1954, pg. 10A, col. 5 and [[Teachers College, Columbia University]]."Dramatic Reader to Appear Saturday," ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]],'' April 4, 1925 And, she was a published composer. * At the [[New England Conservatory]], she had studied three semesters from 1901 to 1902. At NEC, she studied piano with [[Edward Danforth Hale]] (1859–1945) and voice with William L. Whitney (1861–1949) and Alena G. Emerson. She took both piano and voice for all three semesters. In addition she took two semesters of Harmony with [[Harry Newton Redman]] (1869–1958) and two semesters of Music in Public School with Samuel Winkley Cole (1848–1926). She did not earn a diploma from [[New England Conservatory]]. * At Teachers College, she received a Departmental Certificate in Music Education on November 25, 1915. She also took a couple of classes. |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1914–1915''' |width="90%"|'''Harry Milton Snow''' (b. 19 Sept 1879, [[Big Lake, Minnesota]]; d. 23 Apr. 1954, [[Los Angeles]]) studied music at the [[New England Conservatory]]''[https://books.google.com/books?id=nmtVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA231 History of the family of Benjamin Snow: who is a descendant of Richard Snow of Woburn, Massachusetts,]'' by [[Frank N. Wilcox|Owen Nelson Wilcox]] (1880–1950), [[Cleveland]]: Press of the Gates Legal Pub. Co. (1907), pg. 231; {{OCLC|6499884}} from the first semester of 1905 (Fall 1904) through the second semester of 1909 and then for two more semesters in 1912 (when he studied only cello with Virginia Stickney (later known as Mrs. Frances Williams Snow; 1886–1972). Harry Snow graduated June 22, 1909, with a diploma in voice as a teacher. His voice teachers were Arthur Dwight Babcock (1875–1970) and Charles Adams White (1856–1928). He also studied piano for seven semesters with Alfred Pietro Angelo Devoto (born 1875). In addition he studied [[solfège]], Italian, drama, [[music history]], [[music theory]], analysis, English, harmony, French, German, school music, and vocal teaching (called Normal Department). |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1917–1938''' |width="90%"|'''Lillian May Parrill''' (1881–1973) served as ''Director'' of what then was a Music Department. North Texas announced her appointment as a new faculty member July 15, 1915. In addition to heading the department, she conducted the chorus, which, in 1929, had 103 members. The next year, 1930, under her direction, the chorus expanded to 150. Parrill was originally from [[Vincennes, Indiana]]. Parrill was a 1913 graduate of the American Institute of Normal Methods, [[Northwestern University]], [[Evanston, Illinois]]. From 1912 to 1914, she was supervisor of public school music in [[Elwood, Indiana]]; from 1914 to 1915, she studied voice with Oscar Saenger (1868–1929) in [[New York City|New York]]; during the summer of 1911, she studied voice with Charles Washburn in [[Chautauqua, New York]]; and during the summer of 1918, she studied voice with John Dennis Mehan in New York In July 1941, in Denton, she married Fred Otis Grissom (1876–1978). She resigned as Associate Professor in September 1941 and henceforth lived in [[Kinmundy, Illinois]], with her husband. She died June 10, 1973, in [[Kinmundy, Illinois]]. Mary Anderson, professor of piano at North Texas, was Perrill's sister. Anderson, a 1909 and 1911 graduate of [[Baylor University]] had studied from 1913 to 1914 at the [[University of Music and Theatre Leipzig|Royal Conservatory of Music in Leipzig]] and in 1918 and again from 1920 to 1921 with Oliver Denton in New York. |-valign="top" |width="10%"|'''1938–1947''' |width="90%"|'''[[Wilfred Conwell Bain]]''' (1908–1997) built the School of Music into one of the largest in the country. By 1940, North Texas was the largest state supported teachers college in the world."W.N. Masters, Pioneer of Teachers College Faculty, Gives Personality Sketch of Each of Presidents Serving Institution," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]],'' April 16, 1940, pg. 10 Bain was appointed in 1938 as head of what then was a "deanless" school of music. In 1945, when what then was North Texas State Teachers College became North Texas State College — a name change that reflected broader offerings — an administrative reorganization gave the School of Music its own dean, which was filled by Bain. He founded and directed the School's [[A cappella|A Cappella]] Choir and the [[UNT Opera|Opera Workshop]]. The A Cappella Choir, one of dozens of the School's performing groups, performed over 500 concerts in five states between 1940 and 1945. In 1945, the choir performed several tours for civilian and Army groups in Texas in camps to promote [[War bond|bond]] sales and entertain sick and wounded service personnel."NTSC School of Music One of the Nation's Largest," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]],'' September 10, 1945, Sec. 5, pg. 3[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/890871 "Music Activities at North Texas State College,"] [[Anna Harriet Heyer]], ''[[Notes (journal)|Notes]],'' Second Series, Vol. 4, No. 2, March 1947, pps. 234–240 |-valign="top" |'''1947–1958''' |'''Walter Hutchinson Hodgson''' (1904–1988), conductor of the school's [[UNT Symphony Orchestra|Symphony Orchestra]] and founding conductor of the Madrigal Singers, and a sacred music scholar, approved (as acting Dean) in 1947 [[Gene Hall]]'s proposal for a bachelor's degree in "Dance Band," the first jazz studies degree offered in the world. In 1958, Dr. Hodgson accepted an offer to become Dean of the Michigan State University School of Music. |-valign="top" |'''1958–1974''' |'''Kenneth Neil Cuthbert''' (1917–1984), who, in addition to serving as dean, was a choral and instrumental conductor. Cuthbert earned a Bachelor of Music in 1940 and a Master of Music in 1942 from the [[University of Wisconsin]]. He also earned a Master of Arts in 1946 and a Doctor of Education in 1947 from [[Teachers College]], [[Columbia University]]. From 1951 to 1958, Cuthbert had served on the faculty at [[East Carolina University]] and from 1948 to 1951 he had served as Dean of the School of Music at [[Illinois Wesleyan University]]. Also prior to his North Texas tenure, he had served as Vice President of the [[National Association of Schools of Music]] for three years."Dr. Cuthbert Named Dean of NTSC Music School," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' June 27, 1958 |-valign="top" |'''1974–1987''' |'''Marceau Chevalier Myers''' (1929–1987), a scholar of American orchestral composers with a strong affinity for [[Charles Ives]], oversaw a surge in enrollment that made the School the nation's second largest within a major university. Myers also spearheaded the planning and completion of the a new Music Complex that had been initiated under Dean Cuthbert. Under Myers' leadership, the school gained greater international acclaim from an expanded touring initiative by several music ensembles – tours that included [[Western Europe]], [[Russia]], [[South America]], and the [[Far East]]. |-valign="top" |'''1987–1988''' |'''Stephen Thomas Farish, Jr.''' (1936–1995), (Interim Dean) was a singer (baritone) and professor of voice. He earned his DMA from the [[University of Illinois]] in 1962 and, that same year, joined the UNT faculty. |-valign="top" |'''1988–1991''' |'''[[Robert Blocker]]''' (UNT MM 70 DMA 72) (born 1946) is the current Dean of the [[Yale School of Music]] (a graduate school) |-valign="top" |'''1991–1992''' |'''Stephen Thomas Farish, Jr.''' (1936–1995) (Interim Dean) |-valign="top" |'''1992–1996''' |'''David Lewis Shrader''' (born 1939), a percussionist and composer, served as Dean for 7 years. In 1996, the UNT Chancellor asked Shrader to serve as Interim Director of Development for the University. The former Director had died. Shrader obliged, serving for one year. Dr. Will May stepped-in as Interim Dean for one year. |-valign="top" |'''1996–1997''' |'''William "Will" Vernon May, Jr.''' (UNT MME 75) (Interim Dean) |-valign="top" |'''1997–1999''' |'''David Lewis Shrader''', oversaw the opening of the Murchison Performing Arts Center in February 1999 – a 40-year institutional objective. |-valign="top" |'''1999–2000''' |'''William "Will" Vernon May, Jr.''' (UNT MME '75) (Interim Dean) |-valign="top" |'''2000–2001''' |'''Thomas Clark''' (born 1949), a composer and trombonist, and now UNT Professor Emeritus, served once as Interim Dean of the College of Music. |-valign="top" |'''2001–2015''' |'''James Copeland Scott''' (born 1943) is a flutist, pianist, and music theory scholar who has researched structural relationship between [[Arnold Schoenberg|Schoenberg]] and [[Brahms]]. |-valign="top" |'''2016–2016 |'''Warren Henry''', Interim Dean January 2016, following Scott's retirement December 2015. |-valign="top" |'''2016–Present |'''John W. Richmond''', Dean August 1, 2016. Prior to his appointment, Richmond served as Professor and Director of the Glenn Korff School of Music at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL; 2003-2016) and as Professor and in various administrative appointments in the School of Music at the University of South Florida-Tampa (USF; 1987-2003). He earned a bachelor’s degree in music education from William Jewell College, a master’s degree in choral conducting from the Conservatory of Music at the University of Missouri at Kansas City, and a Ph.D. degree in music education from Northwestern University. Richmond’s research focuses on arts education policy, legal issues in arts education, and the philosophy of music education. ---- |-valign="top" |'''Notes:''' |'''Frank Douglas Mainous''' (1918–2007), a composer, [[music theory]] [[scholar]], and director of [[military band]]s during [[World War II]], served as interim dean at least twice. He was married to concert pianist and faculty member Jean Mainous, ''{{linktext|née}}'' Harris.Obituary: "Frank Douglas Mainous," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]]'', April 17, 2007 He earned a Master of Music degree from the [[Eastman School of Music]] in 1941. |} == Selected history == * 1890 — when the University of North Texas was founded – music was a part of the curriculum. What then was a teachers college offered a "Conservatory Music Course" as part of the initial "Nine Full Courses." The complete course in music, lasting forty-four weeks, required private lessons that had to be paid for, in addition to regular school tuition. Tuition for these classes was $200 for the complete course, while regular tuition for a forty-week school year was only $48. The founding president, Joshua Crittenden Chilton (1853–1896), taught the first classes in the history of music and the theory of sound. John M. Moore, a Dallas Methodist bishop and teacher of mathematics and engineering courses, taught the classes in voice culture and harmony. [[Mrs. Eliza Jane McKissack]] was also a teacher of music and may have served as the director of the music conservatory. * 1939 — North Texas became an associate member of the [[National Association of Schools of Music]] * 1940 — North Texas became a full member of the [[National Association of Schools of Music]] * 1941 — The [[National Association of Schools of Music]] approved graduate studies in music at North Texas"Bain Re-Elected Officer in NASM," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' January 5, 1943 * 1950 — The School of Music began offering its first degrees leading to a [[Doctor of Philosophy]] in the areas of [[musicology]], [[music composition|composition]], and [[music theory|theory]]. * 1960 — The oldest existing part of the current Music Building opens, along with Voertman Concert Hall. * 1968 — The [[Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board]] approved degrees leading to a [[Doctor of Musical Arts]] * 1975 — Most of the current Music building opens. * 1989 — The School of Music restructured itself as a "[[college of music]],"{{cite journal|title=It's "College of Music" Now|journal=Reverberations|date=Winter 1989|url=https://digital.library.unt.edu/ark:/67531/metadc181752/|publisher=University of North Texas College of Music}} reflecting nearly 60 years of size and breadth of many disciplines in the music arts. The school leadership had long contemplated restructuring as a [[conservatory of music|conservatory]], but felt that a well-functioning college model, tailored specifically for North Texas, gave the entire university latitude to exploit the best of several models that included academic research, performance, composition, training music educators and music school administrators, and other areas – and it preserved a streamline of cross-discipline of all areas within the College of Music and within the University. The College of Music has enjoyed close collaboration with other Colleges within the University (''e.g.'', English faculty and students collaborating with composers, physics faculty and students collaborating with several divisions in areas that included musical acoustics, electronic music). Despite the high caliber of student musicianship and seriousness of all the programs, the College of Music is accessible in many areas to non-music majors. {{wide image|UNT winspear night.jpg|900px|
'''Murchison Performing Arts Center'''
'''College of Music'''
|alt='''Murchison Performing Arts Center'''
'''College of Music'''}} == See also == {{Main article|University of North Texas Symphony Orchestra}} {{Main article|University of North Texas College of Music Opera}} {{Main article|One O'Clock Lab Band}} {{Main article|University of North Texas Music Library}} {{Main article|List of University of North Texas College of Music alumni}} {{Main article|List of University of North Texas College of Music faculty}} {{Main article|University of North Texas}} :''[[:Category:University of North Texas College of Music alumni]]'' :''[[:Category:University of North Texas College of Music faculty]]'' == References == {{reflist|30em|refs= ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=uEqJXwQHe6kC&pg=PA21 The Story of North Texas,]'' by James Lloyd Rogers (1926–2006), [[University of North Texas Press]] (2002); {{OCLC|49935959}} "Doctoral Programs Expanded," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' April 28, 1968, Sec. H. pg. 5 "University of North Texas College of Music," ''[[Handbook of Texas]]'' {{url|https://tshaonline.org}} (2011) "University of North Texas College of Music," by Warren Henry, PhD, ''The Grove Dictionary of American Music'' (2nd ed.), February 24, 2010, [[Oxford University Press]] {{url|www.oxfordmusiconline.com}}; {{OCLC|774021205|219650052}} [http://www.kinmundyhistoricalsociety.org/Memories/Grissom%20autobiography%201976.pdf "My Hundred Years in Illinois, 1876–1976,"] by Fred Otis Grissom, {{url|www.kinmundyhistoricalsociety.org}} (1976) "New State Normal Teachers — Four Additional Members of Faculty Chosen for North Texas Institution at Denton," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' pg 8, July 16, 1915 "Personals," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]],'' July 18, 1941, pg. 4 "Denton Teachers: Eleven Added to Staff for Long Session," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' September 14, 1941 "Area Deaths, Lillian Parrill Grissom," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]],'' June 15, 1973, pg. 2, col. 3 "Musical Organizations Active a Teachers College; Chorus to Start Work Soon on Christmas Program," ''[[Denton Record-Chronicle]],'' October 18, 1929 "The Story Behind the Song Will Be Luncheon Subject," ''[[Dallas Morning News]],'' February 26, 1930 ''[https://archive.org/stream/catalog1919nort/catalog1919nort_djvu.txt Bulletin of the North Texas State Norman College,]'' No. 64 (issued quarterly), July 1920 }} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.music.unt.edu/}} * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uzgK4cECc4o Video: UNT Symphony Orchestra, David Itkin conducting, Verdi's ''Requiem,'' Movements 2 & 3'', Winspear Hall] {{coord|33.210731|-97.150501|display=title}} {{UNT Music}} {{University of North Texas}} [[Category:Music education in the United States]] [[Category:Music schools in Texas]] [[Category:Performing arts education in the United States]] [[Category:University of North Texas schools, colleges, and departments|Music]] [[Category:Texas classical music]] [[Category:Music of Denton, Texas]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in 1890]]

{{Infobox University |name = University of the Faroe Islands |native_name = Fróðskaparsetur Føroya |latin_name = Academia Færoensis |image = [[Image:UFI Seal.png|150px|Seal of the University of the Faroe Islands]] |established = 1965 |motto = Mildar veittrar tendraðu ein vita føroyum stjørnuleið frá øld til øld | motto_lang = [[Faroese language|Faroese]] | mottoeng = Gentle elves set light to lead the Faroes on the starry way from age to age |type = [[Public university|Public]] |budget = 68,178,000 [[Danish kroner|DKK]] (2010) | undergrad = 558 (2010) | postgrad = 23 (2010) | doctoral = 5 (2010) | other = 65 (2010) |staff = |faculty = 45 |rector = [[Sigurð í Jákupsstovu]] |city = [[Tórshavn]] |country = [[Faroe Islands]] |affiliations= [[UArctic]] |endowment = |website = [http://www.setur.fo www.setur.fo] |logo = Logouniversityfaroeislands.jpg }} [[File:Torshavn map - university.png|thumb|Map of a part of Tórshavn, showing where the university buildings are located.]] The '''University of the Faroe Islands''' ({{lang-fo|Fróðskaparsetur Føroya}}) is a [[Public university|state-run university]] located in [[Tórshavn]], the capital of the [[Faroe Islands]]. It consists of two faculties: the Faculty of Humanities, Social Sciences and Education and the Faculty of Natural and Health Sciences. The university offers [[bachelor's degree|bachelor's]], [[master's degree|master's]], and [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]]'s in both faculties. The student body is small, having almost 600 students. The university organizes an annual dissertation competition open to all students. The educational language of the university is [[Faroese language|Faroese]], making it the only university in the world to conduct classes officially in that language. The university works closely with the [[University of Copenhagen]] and the [[University of Iceland]] for research projects and is a member of [[University of the Arctic|UArctic]].
==History== The University of the Faroe Islands was founded in 1965 by members of the [[Faroese scientific society|Faroese Scientific Society]], founded in 1952.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/soega/|title=The history|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=22 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129050912/http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/soega/|archive-date=29 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Among their activities, the Society published a scientific periodical and carried out comprehensive work on the compilation of [[Faroese language|Faroese]] vocabulary.
The university began with one professor, [[Christian Matras (poet)|Christian Matras]], and a registrar, Maud Heinesen. In its first years the school offered one-year courses in natural history and [[Faroese language|Faroese]] for teachers. In addition to the yearly courses, the university arranged for a collection committee with the task of preserving all [[Faroese language|Faroese]] folk culture. Today this material is in the archives of the Faculty of [[Faroese language|Faroese]] Language and Literature. A further committee was appointed in 1972 to collect [[Faroese language|Faroese]] hymns and spiritual ballads.
On 1 August 2008 the Faroese School of Education and the Faroese School of Nursing where incorporated into the University becoming its departments.<ref name="uniabout">{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/|title=About the University|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=22 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129050905/http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/|archive-date=29 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Organisation and administration== The University of the Faroe Islands is administered by a Board of Directors made up by of seven members.<ref name="board">{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/styrid/|title=Board of Directors of the University of the Faroe Islands|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref> Four of its members are appointed directly by the [[List of Cultural Ministers of the Faroe Islands|minister]] while the remaining three are appointed on recommendation from the university.<ref name="board"/> The Board of Directors is responsible for appointing the [[Rector (academia)|rector]].<ref name="structure">{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/bygnadur-og-leidsla/|title=Organisation and structure|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=30 November 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129050909/http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/bygnadur-og-leidsla/|archive-date=29 November 2014|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The seat of the rector is currently held by [[Sigurd í Jákupsstovu]].<ref name="structure"/>
The University of the Faroe Islands is publicly funded.<ref name="uniabout"/> In 2010 the University's was allocated 68,178,000 [[Danish kroner|DKK]] by the [[Politics of the Faroe Islands#Current government|government]].<ref name="uniabout"/> Apart from the government the university also gets funding for specific projects from the Danish Agency for Science, Technology and Innovation as well as from the private sector.<ref name="uniabout"/> The university is a member of [[University of the Arctic|UArctic]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.uarctic.org/memberslist.aspx?m=589|title=Members List|publisher=University of the Arctic|accessdate=30 November 2014}}</ref>
==Academic profile== The University of the Faroe Islands is divided in two faculties: The Faculty of Humanities, Social Sciences and Education and the Faculty of Natural and Health Sciences.<ref name="structure"/> The Faculty of Humanities, Social Sciences, and Education is divided in the Department of Faroese Language and Literature, the Department of Education, and the Department of History and Social Sciences, while the Faculty of Natural and Health Sciences is divided in the Department of Science and Technology and the Department of Nursing.<ref name="structure"/>
The University offers a total of ten different [[Bachelor's degree]]s: *BA Faroese Language and Literature *BSc History *BSc Social Analysis and Planning *BSc Politics and Administration (political science) *Bachelor of Education in Education with Primary and Lower Secondary School Teacher Qualification *Bachelor of Education in Social Education with Social Educator Qualification *BSc Nursing *BSc Software Engineering *BSc Biology *BSc Energy and Environmental Engineering
Two [[Master's Degree]]s: *MA in Faroese Language and Literature *Masters of Law
And a joint master's degree in cooperation with the [[University of Greenland]], the [[University of Akureyri]], the [[University of Iceland]], and the [[University of Nordland]]:<ref name="structure"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/foeroyamalsdeildin/utbugving/ma-i-foeroyskum/|title=MA degree programme in Faroese language and literature|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/history-and-social-sciences/education/ma-utbugving-i-loegfroedi/|title=Master Degree Programme in Law|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/history-and-social-sciences/education/master-in-west-nordic-studies/|title=Joint Master’s Programme in West Nordic Studies, Governance and Sustainable Management|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> *MA/MSc West Nordic Studies, Governance and Sustainable Management.
For 2010 there were reported 146 students in the Department of Nursing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hagstova.fo/en/statbank/nursing-college-students-class-2003-2010|title=Nursing College, students by class|publisher=Hagstova Føroya|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> A further 266 students were reported in the Department of Education (formerly the Faroese Teachers Training School) <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hagstova.fo/en/statbank/faroese-teachers-training-school-students-education-class-and-gender-200001-201011|title=The Faroese Teachers Training School, students by education, classes, year and gender |publisher=Hagstova Føroya|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> Finally there were 146 undergraduate students, 23 postgraduate students, 5 Ph.D. candidates, and 65 students who took single courses or minor subjects in the other departments.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hagstova.fo/en/statbank/university-faroe-islands-students-education-and-gender-199899-201011|title=The University of the Faroe Islands, students by education, year and gender |publisher=Hagstova Føroya|date=1 November 2011|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref>
===Research=== Research is a priority of the University of the Faroe Islands. Its mission is to increase knowledge within the university and in Faroese society.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/um-setrid/endamal/|title=Purpose|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref name="research">{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/gransking/|title=Research|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref> Research is focused on various fields including [[linguistics]] and literature of Faroese language, education, didactics, [[competitiveness]], [[democracy]], [[weather]], [[Tide|tidal stream]]s, [[Wind wave|waves]] and [[aquaculture]].<ref name="research"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/soegu-og-samfelagsdeildin/gransking/evnisoeki/|title=Ensuring Faroese Competitiveness |publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://setur.fo/en/natturuvisindadeildin/gransking/verkaetlanir/|title=Research Projects|publisher=University of the Faroe Islands|accessdate=2 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gransking.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=13516|title=Department of language and literature|publisher=The Faroese Research Council|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gransking.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=13518|title=Department of History and Social Sciences|publisher=The Faroese Research Council|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gransking.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=13517|title=Department of Science and Technology|publisher=The Faroese Research Council|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gransking.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=13519|title=Department of Education|publisher=The Faroese Research Council|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref> The Research Center for Social Development is an institution connected with the university which undertakes 3 to 5-year research projects.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gransking.fo/Default.aspx?pageid=13521|title=The Research Center for Social Development|publisher=The Faroese Research Council|accessdate=7 December 2014}}</ref>
==Noted people== * [[Christian Matras (poet)|Christian Matras]], founder and first professor of the university. * [[Dorete Bloch]], zoologist * [[Jógvan á Lakjuni]], [[alumnus]].
==See also== * [[Education in the Faroe Islands]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.setur.fo Official website of the University] {{fo icon}} {{en icon}}
{{coord|62|00|26|N|6|46|48|W|source:kolossus-plwiki|display=title}}
