{{Expand French|date=October 2017|Université Grenoble-Alpes}} {{Infobox university | name = Université Grenoble Alpes | image =Université_Grenoble_Alpes.png | image_size = 200px | image_alt = Grenoble-Alpes-logo | latin_name = Universitas Gratianopolitana | motto = ''Veritas Liberabit'' | motto_lang = la | mottoeng = Truth shall set you free | type = [[Public university|Public]] | established = {{start date|1339}} | president = Patrick Lévy | founder = [[Humbert II of Viennois]] | budget = €450 million{{cite web|url=http://www.univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/fr/grandes-missions/universite/|title=Université|first=Université Grenoble|last=Alpes|publisher=}} | academic_staff = 3,000 | administrative_staff = 2,500 | students = 45,000 | undergrad = | postgrad = | doctoral = | other = | city = Cities of [[Grenoble]], [[Saint-Martin-d'Hères]] & [[Gières]] | country = in [[France]] | campus = [[Urban area|Urban]]/[[College town]]
{{Convert|432|acre|ha}} | former_name = University of Grenoble
(1339–1971) | affiliations = [[Aurora (university network)|Aurora]], [[European University Association|EUA]], [[Agence universitaire de la Francophonie|AUF]], [[SGroup European Universities' Network|SGroup]], [[Community Université Grenoble Alpes]] | colors = Red & Gray
{{color box|#E43134}} {{color box|#575757}} | athletics = | sports = | athletics_nickname = | mascot = | sporting_affiliations = | website = {{URL|www.univ-grenoble-alpes.fr}} }} The '''Université Grenoble Alpes''' ('''UGA''', [[French language|French]]: meaning "''Grenoble Alps University''") is a [[Public university|public]] [[research university]] in [[Grenoble]], [[France]]. Founded in 1339, it is the third largest university in France with about 45,000 students and over 3,000 researchers. Established as the '''University of Grenoble''' by [[Humbert II of Viennois]], it split in 1971 following the [[May 1968 events]]. Three of the University of Grenoble's inheritors—[[Joseph Fourier University]], [[Pierre Mendès-France University]], and [[Stendhal University]]—reunited in 2016 to restore the original institution under the name Université Grenoble Alpes. The university is organized around two closely located urban campuses: Domaine Universitaire of 175 ha which straddles [[Saint-Martin-d'Hères]] and [[Gières]], and Campus GIANT of 250 ha in [[Grenoble]]. UGA also owns and operates facilities in [[Valence, Drôme|Valence]], [[Chambéry]], [[Les Houches]], [[Villar-d'Arêne]], [[Mirabel, Ardèche|Mirabel]], [[Échirolles]], and [[La Tronche]].{{cite web|url=http://www.communaute-univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/fr/presentation/chiffres-cles/|title=ComUE - Les chiffres-clés de la Communauté Université Grenoble Alpes|website=www.communaute-univ-grenoble-alpes.fr}}{{cite web|url=http://www.giant-grenoble.org/en/30-000-men-and-women-joining-forces-to-build-a-world-class-campus/|title=Oppportunities|publisher=}} The city of [[Grenoble]] is one of the largest scientific centers in Europe,{{cite web |first1=Mark |last1=Esposito |date=November 2011 |title=The Grenoble Cluster of Minalogic: France's most competitive pole? |url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237009624 }}{{cite web|url=http://www.virgile-adam.com/grenoble|title=Virgile Adam, PhD|website=Virgile Adam, PhD}} hosting facilities of every existing public research institution in France. This allows UGA to have hundreds of research and teaching partnerships, including close collaboration with the [[French National Centre for Scientific Research]] (CNRS) and the [[French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission]] (CEA). Overall, Grenoble as a city is the largest research center in France after Paris with 22,800 researchers. UGA is traditionally known for its research and education in the [[natural science]]s and [[engineering]], but also [[law]], [[linguistics]], and [[psychology]].{{cite web|url=http://www.communaute-univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/en/news/universite-grenoble-alpes-continues-to-stand-out-in-international-rankings-598929.htm|title=ComUE - Université Grenoble Alpes continues to stand out in international rankings|website=www.communaute-univ-grenoble-alpes.fr}}http://www.communaute-univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/medias/fichier/cp-qsranking-mars2014_1412595630344-pdf It has been cited among the best and most innovative universities in Europe.{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/amers-reuters-ranking-innovative-univers-idUSL2N1C406D|title=Reuters Top 100: The World's Most Innovative Universities - 2016|date=28 September 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters|newspaper=Reuters}}https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/europe{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-innovative-stories-europe-idUSKCN0Z00CT|title=Europe's Most Innovative Universities|date=14 June 2017|publisher=|via=Reuters|newspaper=Reuters}} It is also renowned for its academic research in humanities and political sciences, hosting some of the largest research centers in France in fields such as [[political science]], [[urban planning]] or the [[sociology of organizations]]. ==History== ===Early history (1339–1800)=== [[File:Dauphin Humbert II.jpg|thumb|left|145px|[[Humbert II of Viennois]], the university's founder]] [[File:Seal First Universty of Grenoble (France).png|thumb|left|145px|First official seal]] The University of Grenoble was founded in May 12, 1339 by [[Humbert II of Viennois]], the last independent ruler of [[Dauphiné]], a state of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. Its purpose was to teach civil and canon law, medicine, and the liberal arts.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=r7kTAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA28|title=The Catholic Encyclopedia: An International Work of Reference on the Constitution, Doctrine, Discipline, and History of the Catholic Church|first1=Charles George|last1=Herbermann|first2=Edward Aloysius|last2=Pace|first3=Condé Bénoist|last3=Pallen|first4=John Joseph|last4=Wynne|first5=Thomas Joseph|last5=Shahan|date=1 January 1913|publisher=Encyclopedia Press|via=Google Books}} It was considered a leader in the [[Renaissance]] revival of the classics and development of liberal arts.{{cite web|url=https://global.britannica.com/topic/Universities-of-Grenoble-I-II-and-III|title=Universities of Grenoble I, II, and III - university, Grenoble, France|publisher=}} Humbert's actions were inspired by his granduncle [[Robert, King of Naples]], at whose royal court Humbert spent his youth.{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/livreducentenai00grengoog#page/n23/mode/2up|title=Livre du centenaire de la faculté de droit: discours, études et documents|website=archive.org|publisher=Typographie et lithographie Allier Frères|year=1906}} King Robert, known as the Wise, skillfully developed Naples from a small port to a lavish city and had a reputation of a cultured man and a generous patron of the arts, friends with such great minds as [[Petrarch]], [[Boccaccio]], and [[Giotto]].Kelly, Samantha, The New Solomon: Robert of Naples (1309-1343) and Fourteenth-Century Kingship, page 2 Google Books Such rich experience contributed to Humbert's intention to create a university in his own state, and to do so he visited [[Pope Benedict XII]] to get a [[papal bull]] of approval. Humbert cared deeply about his students, offering generous aid, protection, and even providing a hundred of them with free housing.{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/livreducentenai00grengoog#page/n25/mode/2up|title=Livre du centenaire de la faculté de droit: discours, études et documents|website=archive.org|publisher=Typographie et lithographie Allier Frères|year=1906}} Humbert's financial losses during the [[Smyrniote crusades]], [[Black Death]], and [[Dauphiné]]'s attachment to France have greatly decreased the activity of the university leading to its closure, since a small mountainous town couldn't support its activity on its own. It was reopened again by [[Louis XI of France]] in 1475 in [[Valence, Drôme|Valence]] under the name [[University of Valence]], while the original university was restored in Grenoble in 1542 by [[Francis de Bourbon, Count of St. Pol]].{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yf0a3OFlq3sC&pg=PA756|title=The Encyclopedia Britannica: A Dictionary of Arts, Sciences, Literature and General Information|first=Hugh|last=Chisholm|date=1 January 1911|publisher=Encyclopedia Britannica Company|via=Google Books}} The two universities were finally reunited in 1565. At that point Grenoble was an important center of law practice in France, thus law practice was at the center of the university education.{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/livreducentenai00grengoog#page/n29/mode/2up|title=Livre du centenaire de la faculté de droit: discours, études et documents|website=archive.org|publisher=Typographie et lithographie Allier Frères|year=1906}} The [[French Revolution]], with its focus on the end to inherited privilege, led to the suppression of most universities in France. To revolutionaries, universities embodied bastions of corporatism and established interests. Moreover, lands owned by the universities and utilized for their support represented a source of wealth and therefore were confiscated, just as property possessed by the Church. ===Modern period (1800–1968)=== In 1805–1808, [[Napoleon]] reestablished faculties of law, letters, and science. The [[Bourbon Restoration]] had temporarily suppressed the Faculty of Letters and the Faculty of Law, but by the 1850s the university's activity had begun rapidly developing again.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aBelc0YcDboC&pg=PA81|title=Science in the Provinces: Scientific Communities and Provincial Leadership in France, 1860-1930|first=Mary Jo|last=Nye|date=1 January 1986|publisher=University of California Press|via=Google Books|isbn=9780520055612}} The development of the sciences at the university was spearheaded by the transformation of Grenoble from a regional center to a major supplier of industrial motors and electrical equipment in 1880s. The faculties were formally inaugurated as the University of Grenoble in 1879 in the newly constructed Place de Verdun.{{cite web|url=http://www.u-grenoble3.fr/1175503255134/0/fiche___article/|title=Accueil|first=Université Grenoble|last=Alpes|publisher=|access-date=2011-02-10|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100114230359/http://www.u-grenoble3.fr/1175503255134/0/fiche___article/|archive-date=2010-01-14|dead-url=yes|df=}} There were around 3000 students in 1930. Significant enrollment growth in the 1960s created pressures on the academic infrastructure of the university; the library [[Suzanne Dobelmann]] helped expand facilities, especially those relating to science and medicine.{{Cite journal|last=Louis|first=Desgraves,|date=1994|title=Suzanne Kravtchenko-Dobelmann (1905-1993)|url=https://www.persee.fr/doc/bec_0373-6237_1994_num_152_2_464348|journal=Bibliothèque de l'École des Chartes|language=fr-FR|volume=152|issue=2}} ===Recent history (1968–present)=== [[File:Ex-UPMF Grenoble Alpes University.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Some of the ex-UPMF facilities]] Following riots among university students in [[May 1968]],{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/page/may1968france|title=France|work=the Guardian|accessdate=21 June 2015}} a reform of French education occurred. The Orientation Act ''(Loi d’Orientation de l’Enseignement Superieur)'' of 1968 divided the old faculties into smaller subject departments, decreased the power of the [[Ministry of National Education (France)|Ministry of National Education]], and created smaller universities, with strengthened administrations.{{cite web|url=http://www.senat.fr/rap/l06-372/l06-3722.html|title=Projet de loi relatif aux libertés des universités|publisher=|accessdate=21 June 2015}} Thus, sharing the fate of all French universities in 1970s, the University of Grenoble was split into four institutions. Each university had different areas of concentration of study and the faculties were divided as follows: * ''Scientific and Medical University of Grenoble'', which in 1987 was renamed [[Joseph Fourier University]] (UJF), for sciences, health, and technology * ''University of Economics and Law'', which in 1987 was renamed [[Pierre Mendès-France University]] (UPMF), for social sciences and humanities ** ''[[Grenoble Institute of Political Studies]]'', affiliated with UPMF and focusing on political science * ''University of Languages and Letters'', which in 1987 was renamed [[Stendhal University]], for arts and languages * ''[[Grenoble Institute of Technology]]'' (''Grenoble-INP'') for engineering On 1 January 2016, the first three institutions reunited to restore the original common institution under the name Université Grenoble Alpes. Although Grenoble-INP remains separate, it is an active member of the [[Community Université Grenoble Alpes]] and cooperates very closely with the university not only in research projects, but also by sharing labs, offering mutual courses and training for students and researchers. ==Governance== The Université Grenoble Alpes is a public institution of scientific, cultural and professional relevance, which, similar to other universities in France, is governed by a board of directors and an academic council elected every four years. The president of the university is elected by the board of Directors after each renewal, and is eligible for re-election once. On 3 December 2015, staff and students from Joseph Fourier University, Pierre Mendès-France University, and Stendhal University voted to elect representatives to the central councils of the new university. On 7 January 2016, the Board of Directors of the Université Grenoble Alpes elected Lise Dumasy as president. It was the first time a woman has been elected to head a merged university in France.[http://www.placegrenet.fr/2016/01/12/lise-dumasy-elue-a-tete-de-luniversite-grenoble-alpes/73153 placegrenet.fr on 12 January 2016, Lise Dumasy élue à la tête de l'université de Grenoble Alpes.] The university is also a member of the [[Community Université Grenoble Alpes]], a [[COMUE]] whose current president is Patrick Lévy. The association allows the humanities and social sciences and natural and formal sciences to be represented in the governance of the entire university system of Grenoble.[http://www.telegrenoble.net/replay/si-on-parlait_35/si-on-parlait-25-janvier-2016_x3odx2e.html Télégrenoble, Émission ''Si on parlait'' du 25 janvier 2016.] ==Academics== {{Infobox world university ranking | ARWU_W = 151-200 | ARWU_W_ref = [http://www.shanghairanking.com/ARWU2017.html Academic Ranking of World Universities 2017] | THE_W = 301-350 | THE_W_ref = institutes|publisher=Université Grenoble Alpes}} {{div col}} * Department of Chemistry and Biology (UFR Chemistry and Biology) * Department of Computer Science, Mathematics and Applied Mathematics departments spread out in six centres bringing together different types of organisations (joint research departments, host teams, platforms, etc.) in the same scientific field.{{cite web|url=https://www.univ-grenoble-alpes.fr/en/main-missions/about-us/organisation/departments-schools-and-institutes/departments-schools-and-institutes-133548.kjsp|title=Departments, schools and (Pôle PEM) * Social Sciences Centre (Pôle SS) {{div col end}} ==Notable people== UGA has a considerable number of notable alumni in several different fields, ranging from academics to political leaders, executives, and artists. ===Politics === Many European politicians have studied law, economics, and languages in UGA, including: [[Reinhold Maier]]; [[Helene Weber]];[[Walther Schreiber]]; [[Michel Destot]]; [[Louis Besson]];[[Thierry Repentin]]; [[André Vallini]]; and [[Geoffrey Acland]]. Other political leaders include: [[Gaétan Barrette]], Minister of Health and Social Services of [[Canada]]; [[Paul Kaba Thieba]], Prime Minister of [[Burkina Faso]]; [[Abderrahmane Benkhalfa]], Minister of Finance of Algeria; [[Hazem El Beblawi]], Prime Minister of [[Egypt]]; [[Richard E. Hoagland]], US Ambassador; [[Abdoulaye Wade]], President of Senegal; [[Driss Basri]], Interior Minister of [[Morocco]]; [[Ahmedou Ould-Abdallah]], Ambassador for [[Mauritania]]; [[Şenkal Atasagun]], Chief of the National Intelligence Organization of [[Turkey]]; [[Ignas Jonynas]], Lithuanian diplomat; [[Souvanna Phouma]], Prime Minister of [[Laos]]; [[Ali Al Shami]], Minister of Foreign Affairs of [[Lebanon]]; [[Fathallah Sijilmassi]], Moroccan politician and economist; [[Mohammed al-Dairi]] Minister of Foreign Affairs of [[Libya]]. UGA alumni also include American journalist [[Warren D. Leary]], French journalists Éric Conan, [[Olivier Galzi]], Françoise Joly, Laurent Mauduit, Philippe Robinet, Caroline Roux, British [[Joanna Gosling]] and [[Safia Shah]], and German [[Jona von Ustinov]], who worked for [[MI5]] during the time of the [[Nazi regime]]. Among social activists who attended UGA, one could find [[Léo-Paul Lauzon]], [[Léa Roback]], [[Austin Mardon]], and the former CEO of the Chicago Urban League [[James Compton]]. Weizsäcker.jpg|[[Richard von Weizsäcker]], President of Germany File:Vigdis Finnbogadottir (1985).jpg|[[Vigdís Finnbogadóttir]], President of Iceland File:Silver Pitcher presented to White House (Portrait).jpg|[[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jacqueline Kennedy]], First Lady of the United States ===Mathematics and sciences=== Numerous prominent scientists have studied at the Université Grenoble Alpes since the development of the hydro-power in the region in 1880s. Prominent fields include physics, material sciences, and computer sciences with alumni like [[Yves Bréchet]],{{cite web|url=http://www.college-de-france.fr/site/yves-brechet/|title=Biographie|website=www.college-de-france.fr}} member of the [[French Academy of Sciences]]; [[Rajaâ Cherkaoui El Moursli]],{{cite web|url=http://www.um5a.ac.ma/index.php/fr/accueil/102-french/622-biographie-r-cherkaoui|title=Biographie R. Cherkaoui|website=www.um5a.ac.ma|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150410025815/http://www.um5a.ac.ma/index.php/fr/accueil/102-french/622-biographie-r-cherkaoui|archivedate=2015-04-10|df=}} who worked on the [[Higgs Boson]] discovery; [[Patrick Cousot]],{{cite web|url=http://www.di.ens.fr/~cousot/cv/short.shtml|title=Patrick Cousot|website=www.di.ens.fr}} French computer scientist; [[Joseph Sifakis]], [[Turing Award]] laureate; Claude Boutron,{{cite web|url=http://www.ae-info.org/ae/Member/Boutron_Claude/CV|title=Academy of Europe: CV|first=Ilire Hasani, Robert|last=Hoffmann|website=www.ae-info.org}} French glaciologist; Jean-Louis Coatrieux,{{cite web|url=https://www.ltsi.univ-rennes1.fr/?q=node/158|title=LTSI : Laboratoire Traitement du Signal et de l'Image - LTSI|website=www.ltsi.univ-rennes1.fr}} French researcher in [[medical imaging]]; Michel Cosnard,{{cite web|url=http://www.letudiant.fr/educpros/personnalites/cosnard-michel.html|title=Michel COSNARD: biographie et actualités sur EducPros|website=www.letudiant.fr}} French computer scientist; [[Paul Trendelenburg]],{{cite journal |doi=10.1007/s00210-006-0051-8 |pmid=16557377 |title=Translating Trendelenburg; back to the future |journal=Naunyn-Schmiedeberg's Archives of Pharmacology |volume=373 |issue=2 |pages=134–138 |year=2006 |last1=Lammers |first1=Wim J. E. P. |last2=Lammers-Van Den Berg |first2=Anne Marijke |last3=Morrison |first3=John F. B. |last4=Petroianu |first4=Georg A. }} German pharmacologist; [[Yousef Saad]],http://www-users.cs.umn.edu/~saad/RES.pdf computer scientist; [[Maurice Nivat]], [[Catherine Ritz]],{{cite web|url=http://www-lgge.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr/axes/rheologie/catritz.html|title=Equipe Meca Personnel [fr]|website=www-lgge.obs.ujf-grenoble.fr}}{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} French Antarctic researcher; [[Eric Goles]], Chilean mathematician; [[Pierre Colmez]], French mathematician; [[René Alphonse Higonnet]],http://www.dmg-lib.org/dmglib/main/biogrViewer_content.jsp?id=24215004&skipSearchBar=1 French engineer; [[Marlon Dumas]], Honduran computer scientist; [[Claire Berger]],{{cite web|url=https://www.physics.gatech.edu/user/claire-berger|title=cb299|first=|last=cb299|date=19 February 2015|publisher=}} French physicist. '''The Wisconsin Idea Theatre''' was essentially a cultural program, developed at the [[University of Wisconsin]] c. 1943. It was headed by [[Robert E. Gard]] within the College of Agriculture, with a mission for developing theatre arts throughout the state. Gard worked with anyone that had an idea, to develop radio dramas, or stage performances. He worked with [[4-H]], seeking to develop children's theatre within the state, as well as encouraging and assisting faith groups to develop dramas based on their faith.<ref name="communityarts" /><ref name="gardfoundation" /><ref name="lakeplacid" />
In 1945, Gard founded the Wisconsin Idea Theatre Conference, which attempted to represent all theatre interests across the state.<ref name="gardfoundation" />
== History == The Wisconsin Idea Theatre began when [[Robert M. La Follette, Sr.]] and [[Charles Van Hise]] attended the University of Wisconsin. They were close friends, both influenced by the progressive ideals of economics professor [[John Bascom]]. La Follette went on to become governor, while Van Hise became President of the University. They had a mutual vision of a government "infused with the talent of trained professionals, guided by the expertise of our wisest scholars and answerable to an active and well-educated citizenry."<ref name="communityarts" />
In order to realise this ideal, they turned the University towards educating not only its students, but encouraging and teaching residents across the state. Correspondence courses were offered, along with traveling faculty. The Governor held regular meetings with the professors of the University to keep in touch, and to encourage their progress.<ref name="communityarts" />
Van Hise's successor, President [[Glen Frank]], had a passion for expanding the arts, and hired [[Dean Chris Christensen]] to head the College of Agriculture, hoping to encourage farmers, and their families to be more creative.<ref name="communityarts" />
Christensen then hired [[Aldo Leopold]], a well-known conservationist, [[John Stuart Curry]], an artist, and [[Robert E. Gard]]. It was Gard that founded the Wisconsin Idea Theatre.<ref name="communityarts" />
== Notes == {{Reflist|refs= <ref name="gardfoundation">[http://www.gardfoundation.org/gard.html Robert E. Gard Biography] Robert E. Gard wisconsin Idea Foundation. (Retrieved 12 March 2011.)</ref> <ref name="communityarts">[http://www.communityarts.net/readingroom/archivefiles/2003/12/report_on_the_a.php The Arts and the Wisconsin Idea: A Conference Report] Maryo Gard Ewell, Community Arts Network (Retrieved 12 March 2011.)</ref> <ref name="lakeplacid">[http://www.lakeplacidnews.com/page/content.detail/id/502923/ON-THE-ARTS--The-Wisconsin-idea.html?nav=5001 ON THE ARTS: The Wisconsin idea] Naj Wikoff, Lake Placid News. October 14, 2010.</ref> }}
== Suggested reading == The Wisconsin Idea Theatre : a program in statewide drama, Junius Eddy, 1949. [http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/005739834 Record at the Hathi Trust Digital Library] {{University of Wisconsin–Madison}}

Many companies are part of an international cultural exchange program that is centered around the US State Departments J-1 Visa Work and Travel program. The US State Department's Summer Work and Travel Program brings more than 100,000 foreign university students to the US each year. All of the students are between the ages of 18 and 28. All are proficient in the English language and all are able to commit to working for at least three months. Some foreign students are able to work in the US for four months and some for five months. The maximum length of stay is determined by the US State Department and is based in part on typical university schedules in each nation. The Summer Work and Travel Program provides foreign students with an opportunity to live and work in the United States during their summer vacation from college or university to experience and to be exposed to the people and way of life in the United States.
==Program overview== {{See also|Summer Work Travel Program#Program details}}
=== Work === Candidates do not normally need to have qualification or experience as training will be given at the place of work as necessary. The types of jobs on offer include sales-people, cashiers, hosts and staff in hotels, restaurants or entertainment parks.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://studyabroad.ua/dpages/vakansii-work-and-travel58/|title=Jobs in the US|last=studio|first=C4 web design|date=|website=studyabroad.ua|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
=== Travel === Applicants may remain in the United States until the end of their exchange program, as specified on form DS-2019. Once a J-1 visitor's program ends, he or she may remain in the United States for an additional 30 days, often referred to as a "grace period", in order to prepare for departure from the country. * The actual J-1 visa certificate does not specifically document this 30-day post-study/exam "grace period", and consequently some airline counter staff have refused to issue a boarding pass to an embarking student. In particular, when the student's return ticket is departing '''after''' the J-1 visa has expired. For example: the return date is the next day after the students last exam. * If the visitor leaves the United States during these 30 days, the visitor may not re-enter with the J-1 visa. The minimal and the maximal duration of stay are determined by the specific J-1 category under which an exchange visitor is admitted into the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://j1visa.state.gov/participants/current/adjustments-and-extensions/|title=Adjustments and Extensions {{!}} Participants {{!}} J-1 Visa|last=State|first=Department of|website=j1visa.state.gov|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
=== Agencies === Agencies are representatives of the student candidates. The agencies are engaged in the search for vacancies with sponsors, will organize the vacancies and prepare the necessary documents for participation. Agencies are also engaged in health and safety issues and are available to help solve any problems which may arise for students during their stay in the USA.
==Legal aspects== {{See also|Summer Work Travel Program#Requirements}} Work and Travel USA students are subject to the [[Summer Work Travel Program]] requirements. The company charges a nominal fee to cover the costs of SEVIS, a program that tracks J-1 visa students and makes their anonymous distribution data publicly available on the J-1 visa website.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://j1visa.state.gov/swt-participants-map/|title=Summer Work Travel Participants Map {{!}} J-1 Visa|last=State|first=Department of|website=j1visa.state.gov|access-date=2017-05-20}}</ref>
In addition to the government requirements, Work and Travel USA students are required to: * Register their information in SEVIS no later than ''10 days'' after arriving in the USA. It varies by each sponsoring organization. * Update their SEVIS information within 10 days, if they change address during the time in the USA or if they switch jobs. * Check-in every ''30 days'' to maintain active status on the program.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.interexchange.org/sevis/|title=SEVIS {{!}} InterExchange|website=InterExchange|access-date=2016-08-29}}</ref>
==Books== * Viking Travel Croatia, General info for the work and travel in the United States <ref>[http://www.vikingtravel.hr General Info for the US Work Travel Program] </ref> * Work and Travel USA 2019' * DOO"Viking Travel Montenegro, Work and Travel in examples; Work and Travel" (2018)<ref>www.vikingtravel.me</ref>
== See also == * [[Student exchange program]]

revision.text:
A '''Writing Fellow''' or '''Fellow in Writing''' is a tutor or [[consultant]] who assists with [[college]] and [[university]] writing instruction in specific [[Academic major|courses]] or academic fields. Whereas most [[Writing Center]] tutors are generalists, ready to work with writing from any course or field, Writing Fellows are specialists. Often working within a Writing Center or Writing Across a Curriculum program, they typically provide oral and/or written feedback on papers to students in an upper-division writing class. A Writing Fellow is most often a [[peer tutor]]; however, the term “Writing Fellow” is also sometimes used for faculty members who advise others on teaching, assigning and responding to student writing in their specific disciplines.
== See also == *[[Writing Center]] *[[Composition studies]]
== External links == * [http://wac.colostate.edu/atd/fellows/index.cfm Special issue of ''Across the Disciplines'' on Rewriting Across the Curriculum: Writing Fellows as Agents of Change in WAC] * [http://www.barnard.edu/writing/writingcenter.html Barnard College Writing Fellows Program] * [http://www.brown.edu/Student_Services/Writing_Fellows/ Brown University Writing Fellows] * [http://www.ccny.cuny.edu/wac/ The City College Writing Fellows Program] * [http://www.falmouth.ac.uk/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=304&Itemid=142 University College Falmouth Writing Fellows] * [http://wac.colostate.edu/fellows/ Writing Across the Curriculum Clearinghouse--List of Writing Fellows Programs] * [http://www.wisc.edu/writing/wf/main.html University of Wisconsin-Madison Undergraduate Writing Fellows Program] * [http://writing.rochester.edu/writing_fellows/index.html University of Rochester Writing Fellows Program] * [https://sites.google.com/site/bewritemit/ MIT's Department of Biological Engineering, Writing Fellow Program]
